headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Nucor Corporation Fourth Quarter and Year-End of 2010 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Certain statements made during this conference call will be forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Nucor Corporation Fourth Quarter and Year-End of 2010 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Certain statements made during this conference call will be forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. The words we expect; believe; anticipate; and variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify those forward-looking statements which are based on management's current expectations and information that is currently available. Although Nucor believes they are based on reasonable assumptions, there can be no assurance that future events will not affect their accuracy. For more information about the risks and uncertainties relating to these forward-looking statements may be found in Nucor's 10-K and subsequently filed 10-Q. Which are available on the SEC's and Nucor's website. The forward-looking statements made in this conference call speak only as of this state, and Nucor does not assume any obligation to update them either as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. 
For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Dan DiMicco, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Nucor Corporation. Please go ahead, sir

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. We want to thank you for joining us for our conference call. As always, we appreciate your interest in Nucor. With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor senior management team, our newly elected President, Chief Operating Offi
componenttext:
Good afternoon. We want to thank you for joining us for our conference call. As always, we appreciate your interest in Nucor. With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor senior management team, our newly elected President, Chief Operating Officer and Board Member,John Ferriola; Chief Financial Officer Jim Prius; and our other Executive Vice President Jim Darsey; Keith Grass, over our raw materials fab operations; Ladd Hall over our flat rolled operations; Ham Lott over our fabricated product division; and Joe Stratman, Business Development and over our been in the operations.
First, as usual and most importantly, we want to thank everyone in our team at Nucor and our Harris Steel and David J. Joseph operations for working safely and working together in what remains an extremely challenging economic environment. The talent and can-do attitude of the Nucor team what our company will continue our long history of emerging from downturns stronger than we entered into them. While a robust, sustainable economic recovery begins, our team's efforts will pay a bit of install members of the Nucor family, particularly the people who own Nucor: Our shareholders.  Again, thank you to all of the 20,000 plus men and women of the Nucor team, and most importantly, continue to work safely.
I will now ask our CFO, Jim Frias, to discuss our fourth quarter results and financial position. Following Jim's comments, President and COO John Ferriola will report on our operations and implementation of our growth initiatives. And then before we take your questions, I will share with you some of my thoughts. Jim?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dan, and good afternoon. With the loss of $0.04 per diluted share, the fourth quarter proved to be the most challenging quarter of 2010 as we predicted. Of particular note, metal margins in our steel mills declined by $27 per ton from third qua
componenttext:
Thank you, Dan, and good afternoon. With the loss of $0.04 per diluted share, the fourth quarter proved to be the most challenging quarter of 2010 as we predicted. Of particular note, metal margins in our steel mills declined by $27 per ton from third quarter levels. A sharp escalation in scrap prices late this fall outpaced our ability to realize mill price increases in time to benefit the fourth quarter. The margin compression was great in that of our flat rolled mills. 
In our mid December guidance, we reported our expectation that the 2010 four-year LIFO charge will be lower than the amount estimated at the end of the third quarter. The fourth quarter LIFO charge of $23 million was down from our average quarterly expense of $47 million at the end of the third quarter, but in line with our guidance estimate. This decline reflected lower year-end units of inventory compared to third quarter. 
Our full year 2010 LIFO charge was $164 million compared with the 2009 LIFO credit of $467 million. Nucor incurred a $10 million charge in the fourth quarter related to the termination of the Highs Mill joint venture in Australia. This charge was not incorporated in the quantitative guidance we gave in mid-December. While the Highs Mill technology still has promise, the partners at decided additional capital expenditures would not be a good investment in the current economic environment. For Nucor, we believe our best iron-making investment opportunities today are in growing our direct reduced iron or DRI I should give abilities. We will continue to build on both the knowledge gained from our highly successful DRI Plant Internet and our long term supplies of attractive price natural gas. 
Fourth quarter results also included $39 million of pre-operating and startup costs. On a quarterly basis, there has been some improvement from the peak level of more than $50 million in 2010's first quarter. For the full year 2010, these expenses totaled $175 million. Nucor typically incur significant pre-operating and startup expenses during economic downturns. We view these cost as investments to grow our long-term earnings power. We look for these new businesses to be significant profit generators in the years ahead. That is in our companies experienced over many three cycles. 
For example, Nucor's most recent cyclical peak earnings of almost $6 per share in 2008 carried sizable benefits and contributions from the startup projects undertaken during the 2001 to 2003 downturn. It goes back to the Dan's point that our team continues Nucor's long history of emerging from downturns stronger than we enter them. Successful execution of this strategy is how we build long-term value for our shareholders. It is our financial strength that allows us to invest in attractive growth opportunities through the economic cycle. At the close of 2010, cash and short-term investments totaled almost $2.5 billion. Not included in that total is an additional $600 million of restricted cash. This restricted cash resulted from our issuance of golf opportunities or goes own funds in November. These tax-exempt bonds were authorized by the state of Louisiana and will finance a significant portion of the $750 million DRI Plant we're building in St. James Parish in Louisiana. 
Further to Nucor's strong liquidity, our $1.3 billion unsecured revolving credit facility is undrawn and does not mature until November 2012. We have no commercial paper outstanding. Long-term debt totaled $4.3 billion at year-end 2010. That is an increase of $1.2 billion from the beginning of the year. Nucor's conservative financial practices and strong balance sheet allowed us to be opportunistic in taking advantage of favorable credit market conditions last year to reduce our overall cost of capital. In addition to November's tax-exempt bond financing, we issued $600 million of 12-year unsecured notes with a coupon rate of 4.125%. That transaction was an excellent opportunity to prepare for upcoming long-term debt maturities of $650 million in 2012 and $250 million in 2013. 
Allowing for these dynamics, Moody's has reported that our debt-to-capital ratio will be viewed on a net debt basis for any cash balances over $1.2 billion. At year-end 2010, that net debt-to-capital ratio was approximately 29%. That calculation excludes restricted cash. Our operating cash flow performance in 2010 highlights another key strength of our business model. Cash provided for buy-to-buy operating activities were nearly $900 million in 2010. That more than covered capital spending of $345 million and cash dividends paid of $457 million for the year. In 2011, we will continue to allocate capital to investments that build our long-term earnings power and provide attractive returns to our shareholders. We project 2011 capital spending of approximately $560 million. Included in that total are about $120 million of spending for our Louisiana DRI Plant and about $60 million for our natural gas working interest drilling program. 
As we enter the first quarter, the trend of improving market conditions that began in the fourth quarter has continued. Steel mill utilization rates have increased then in fact, fourth quarter shipments increased 32% over third quarter levels. We have been able to significantly raise mill selling prises in response to rising raw material costs and some improvement in and use demand. Downstream fabricated Construction Products markets remain very challenging. Overall, we expect a return to profitability in the first quarter. And we believe the positive trend in earnings will continue into the second quarter.
We'll again file all our practice of providing quantitative guidance in the final month of the quarter. In the long-term, we're very optimistic about Nucor's prospects to continue building attractive and sustainable long-term value for our shareholders. Our team is working hard very effectively to capitalize in our company's position of strength. Thank you for your interest in Nucor.
Dan?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. Good afternoon. Let me begin by thanking all of our raw materials, steelmaking and steel products teammates for your outstanding commitment to working safely and taking care of Nucor's customers. We are extremely proud of the work that you ar
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. Good afternoon. Let me begin by thanking all of our raw materials, steelmaking and steel products teammates for your outstanding commitment to working safely and taking care of Nucor's customers. We are extremely proud of the work that you are doing in the tough economic times that have been with us for more than two years. Thank you, and please keep it going.
My report can be summarized in this one sentence: For Nucor, downturns create opportunities, opportunities for profitable growth. Here are some examples of how we are coming out of the economic downturn stronger than we entered it. Nucor's plate and structural mills are doing an excellent job of growing our market during the current downturn. Highlighting the gains, these mills are shipped to total of 240,000 tons of products that were not even offered in our mix two years ago. Even better, their work continues. Our preferred County North Carolina plate mills new heat treat line was commissioned in the fourth quarter of 2010, and it is quickly ramping up to its full capacity of 125,000 tons per year. The product coming off of this line is everything we hoped it would be: Great shape, great service and write on speck.  This investment allows to go into higher margin products were higher strained, a greater resistance and greater toughness are required. 
Our Tuscaloosa, Alabama plate mill team has continued to improve our recently added Temple line so that it's now capable of running one inch thick plates. This will allow us to sell as much as 250,000 tons per year of higher margins of the length blades rather than commodity powered coiled. Just as exciting, the Tuscaloosa team has used their ingenuity and virtually no capital to start producing the end of the hot mill. We expect to be able to produce as much as 125,000 tons per year of this higher valued, higher margin discrete plate at Tuscaloosa due to these improvements.
Although these projects at Hartford County in Tuscaloosa will not increase our total plate capacity, they will have the combined effect of moving more than 500,000 annual tons of plate output from commodity grades to higher value grades that generate higher margins per ton. That of course means higher earnings power in the future from our plate mills.  And we will not stop there in expanding our portfolio of margin enhanced plate products to better serve our customers and generate greater profits for our shareholders.
We recently approved the capital to install a vacuum gas in the Hartford County. Commissioning is expected in the first quarter of 2013. This will further broaden our product mix to include all the plate and served alloy plate grades. Our Bomill group is also growing Nucor's long-term earnings power with a number of projects that have started up during the current downturn. These include our new SBQ mill in Memphis and our wire rod and coiled rebar rolling mill in Arizona. The Memphis mill more than doubles our capacity to serve the SBQ markets while also expanding our product range into the highly attractive 3-inch and 10-inch larger diameter segment.  Memphis continues to gain product qualifications and production volumes for OEMs in the construction equipment, automotive, heavy truck, farm equipment and energy markets.  In December, our Memphis team set a record for shipments of rolled finished goods. 
With the addition of our low-cost rolling mill in Arizona, Nucor can now serve all regions of the country with our wire rod products. Our Nucor Steel came in team also is at our shipment record in December and recently expanded from a single shift to double shift operations.
Reflecting our cultures drive for continual improvement and profitable growth, there is more to come. For example, Nucor Steel Nebraska will be adding a downstream processing line that provides new growth opportunities and even higher-quality SBQ products than they currently offer. Additionally, our bar mills in Texas, Utah and South Carolina, along with our Nucor model being mill has established NQA1 quality systems that allow them to supply steel to nuclear power plant construction projects.
Nucor's sheep mill group is also continuing to what the value chain, with margin enhanced products that grow long-term earnings power. Building on Nucor Steel Berkeley while value-added bakken degas steel, we will be installing a second sheet mill bakken degasser at our Hickman, Arkansas facility. As though westernmost flat rolled facility in the United States, where the back end the gas Nucor Steel Arkansas will be strategically positioned to take advantage of the growing market to the West, Southwest and Mexico. Already, over 20% of all the gas deals currently sold in the U.S. are purchased by OEMs located in states adjacent Arkansas. 
In addition to the opportunities to expand our current market share with existing customers in automotive, HVAC, and oil country tubular goods, the Hickman degasser will enable us to develop new customers and target markets such as motor laminations, garage doors and lawn-and-garden.
We expect commissioning took our in the fourth quarter of 2012.
I will close my report with our thoughts on current market conditions. The market environment for our fabricated Construction Products business continues to be extremely challenged, and it has been for some time. We have been working throughout 2010 to raise prices in each of the industries in which we participate, with varying degrees of success. In addition to seeing some measured success in achieving price increases, we have seen our market share increase strongly in several of our downstream businesses. In our ball crop Verco group, we achieved significant market share increases in both joint and deck in 2010. In our Metal Buildings group, we obtained an even greater market share increase. We also signed up a large number of new builders. Builders are the distribution chain in that industry. And we bought fabrication we purchased several small fabricators in the Southeast and another one in Texas.
We want to thank all of our teammates in those businesses for their excellent work in making the best of the very difficult environment. Despite the challenging times, they are unrelenting and demonstrating the Nucor can-do spirit by working safely, working hard and staying focused on continuous improvement.
On the Steelmaking side, we are encouraged by recent signs of some improvement in wheel demand. However, it is difficult to determine how much of the overall increase in a parent demand is driven by steel buyers reacting to increasing raw material and steel prices.
Fortunately, service center inventories through December remain at relatively low levels. It is our belief that real demand will continue to grow gradually throughout 2011.
The December AIA Architecture Building Index suggest non-residential construction activity may start growing again in late 2011.  We view 2011  with cautious optimism. An optimism anchored by our ongoing view that the U.S. economy is likely to experience a gradual recovery due to structural imbalances that must be addressed by our elected officials. In addition, we are keeping more than a watchful eye on influence that continued to have two great a share of the U.S. market at a time when our low-cost domestic industry is still running at only 70% of capacity. We are focused on taking preemptive trade actions as a more supportive administration and Congress has shown a willingness to do. But whatever direction the economy takes over the short term, our team is primed and ready to utilize Nucor's position of strength and our extremely flexible business model to continue to generate long-term earnings for our shareholders.
Thank you for your interest in Nucor. Dan?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. There is one loud and clear message coming from these reports from Jim and John. The Nucor team is building long-term value for our shareholders. And we have had a successful record that extends over nearly five decades of doing just that
componenttext:
Thank you, John. There is one loud and clear message coming from these reports from Jim and John. The Nucor team is building long-term value for our shareholders. And we have had a successful record that extends over nearly five decades of doing just that. Its' worthwhile to look at the long-term value we have generated over the last cycle. From the cyclical trough and in our stock price in the 7th of September of 2001 when the new executive team started to 2010 closing price, our long-term shareholders enjoyed a more than 7.3x increase in the value of their investment including dividends, 7.3x. Speaking of dividends, in December, our board increased are regular quarterly cash dividend for the 38th consecutive year. And over the period from 2000 and 2010, Nucor's based dividend has increased approximately tenfold. is returned star shareholders from growth in our stock price and pay cash dividends have not just happened by accident or by writing a cyclical upturn. They were achieved by building sustainable business that is generated large returns on capital in the North American steel industry over that 2000 to 2010 time span. And they reflect our teams' unrelenting focus of being effective stewards of our shareholders valuable capital. 
In our long-term focus and approach to managing our business has been constant to this most recent severe recession. Nucor continue to make substantial investments to position us for our new high-rise earnings power once the sustainable economic recovery arrives.
What exactly what we mean when we say growing strong returning downturns? From 2007 to our expected 2011 capital spending plans, we have invested more than $6 billion of capital, including both capital expenditures and acquisitions. That is a lot of capital that Nucor shareholders will get paid for to attract the returns as they move to the next obstacle. Our team is very optimistic about Nucor's prospects for rewarding our shareholders with attractive long-term returns, just like we've been doing. Why? Because as a team, we're driven to sell for nothing less. 
Finally, I will close with some very exciting news received just today. We have received the final permit for our 22.5 million tons plant in Louisiana. These facilities will produce high-quality  DRI to use our SBQ plates and sheet mills. Initially we will build the plant. To expand to the solidity shortly thereafter. These plants will enable a second allow for greater self sufficiency, controlling more of our own raw materials, along with assuring us of high-quality raw material feed. We anticipate starting construction immediately, and we have placed orders for the major equipment irons already with our suppliers.
We have an anticipated startup of mid-2013. The Nucor team is excited to be part of the same Louisiana and bringing in the type high-paying jobs that would help make us interval partners community. We appreciate all of the help and support that govern Bobby Jindall and all the others to local agencies have given to us to help this process come to fruition.
Once again, thank you for your interest in Nucor and we would now be happy to take your questions.

componenttext: 2010 is actually the year we saw the bottom of our and the construction markets and it was in 2009, it was 2010. And yes, we do believe we have reached the bottom and that we're seeing some positive demand signs. But they're not rapid and they're not large. We have seen some improvements in the architectural index one of the faults of that index is that it includes all of the architectural activities whether its domestic or foreign. so you have to be very careful judging the actual uptick in non-res and construction just from the AIA numbers you have to take into account more factors than that. But indeed, we have seen things improve. We have come up the bottom of this company has slow, gradual climb. There's really nothing going on out there that's going to change things in a dramatic fashion in the first quarter but we do expect to see steady improvement throughout the year-end we do expect to see the ability to maintain strong pricing to cover are raw material cost about the year

componenttext: Your can expect that the second phase, the second DRI plant will go into the lower cost in the 750 because the equipment in the facility that will handle both of those operations will be put in there for the first operation. And the original permit that we have in hand and that has been modified for the first phase now that we have two DRI Plants, the original covered three phases. And currently, the second phase is still planned to be a blast furnace coke oven operation and the third phase to be finishing and rolling, maybe steelmaking operations, depending on how the market develops over the next several years and so the total investment could be significantly greater than $3 billion and you've seen numbers in the past that were $6 billion. But those numbers include a blast furnace and coke ovens and associated support equipment and power plants for the first phase being glass furnace as opposed to now being DRI plans. So there a lot of numbers that are out therefore the latest number that we have in the press release covers predominantly the two DRI plants and potentially an operation at that facility, and all the material handling equipment.

The best gauge that we can give you is doesn't what are telling you because we've been very conservative and pretty spot on as to what is really going on from time to time to time and we're saying to you today that things are getting better and they're getting better slowly. And if any provides a contrary information to that, then I don't think they're giving information to that And the main things we look at our the things you mentioned and we can't predict what's going on for scrap even though we have major scrap processing and brokerage company within the company. Scrap not the same environment today as it has 20 years ago. Scrap move $15, $20 a year there was a big move. That's not the case for the last seven years. It's because of global demand, it's become much more volatile so you're predicting when that is going to happen it's still doesn't go to do a despite our best efforts because we don't control really what goes on in these markets in a global world. It's much more complicated than that. But at the end of the day, GDP growth has grown over 3% is going to be slow growth for the steel industry.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Nucor Corporation Fourth Quarter and Year End of 2010 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Certain statements made during this conference call will be forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. The words we expect, believe, anticipate and variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify those forward-looking statements, which are based on management's current expectations and information that is currently available. Although Nucor believes they are based on reasonable assumptions, there can be no assurance that future events will not affect their accuracy. For more information about the risks and uncertainties relating to these forward-looking statements may be found in the Nucor's 10-K and subsequently filed 10-Q, which are available on the SEC's and Nucor's website. The forward-looking statements made in this conference call speak only as of this date, and Nucor does not assume any obligation to update them either as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. 
For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Dan DiMicco, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Nucor Corporation. Please go ahead, sir

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. We want to thank you for joining us for our conference call. As always, we appreciate your interest in Nucor. With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor senior's management team, our newly elected President, Chief Operating Of
componenttext:
Good afternoon. We want to thank you for joining us for our conference call. As always, we appreciate your interest in Nucor. With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor senior's management team, our newly elected President, Chief Operating Officer and Board Member,John Ferriola; Chief Financial Officer Jim Frias; and our other Executive Vice President Jim Darsey over our Long Products; Keith Grass over our Raw Materials Scrap operations; Ladd Hall over our Flat Rolled operations; Ham Lott over our Fabricated Product divisions; and Joe Stratman, Business Development and over our Beam and Plate operations.
First, as usual and most importantly, we want to thank everyone in our team at Nucor and our Harris Steel and David J. Joseph operations for working safely and working together in what remains an extremely challenging economic environment. The talent and can-do attitude of the Nucor team are why our company will continue our long history of emerging from downturns stronger than we entered into them. When a robust, sustainable economic recovery inevitably begins, our team's efforts will pay big dividends to all members of the Nucor family; particularly the people who own Nucor, our shareholders.  Again, thank you to all of the 20,000 plus men and women of the Nucor team, and most importantly, continue to work safely.
I will now ask our CFO, Jim Frias, to discuss our fourth quarter results and financial position. Following Jim's comments, President and COO, John Ferriola will report on our operations and implementation of our growth initiatives. And then before we take your questions, I will share with you some of my thoughts. Jim?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dan, and good afternoon. With a loss of $0.04 per diluted share, the fourth quarter proved to be the most challenging quarter of 2010 as we predicted. Of particular note, metal margins at our steel mills declined by $27 per ton from third quart
componenttext:
Thank you, Dan, and good afternoon. With a loss of $0.04 per diluted share, the fourth quarter proved to be the most challenging quarter of 2010 as we predicted. Of particular note, metal margins at our steel mills declined by $27 per ton from third quarter levels. A sharp escalation in scrap prices late this fall outpaced our ability to realize mill price increases in time to benefit the fourth quarter. The margin compression was great as that of our flat rolled mills. 
In our mid-December guidance, we reported our expectation that the 2010 four-year LIFO charge would be lower than the amount estimated at the end of the third quarter. The fourth quarter LIFO charge of $23 million was down from our average quarterly expense of $47 million at the end of the third quarter, but in line with our guidance estimate. This decline reflected lower year-end units of inventory compared to third quarter. 
Our full year 2010 LIFO charge was $164 million compared with the 2009 LIFO credit of $467 million. Nucor incurred a $10 million charge in the fourth quarter related to the termination of the HIsmelt joint venture in Australia. This charge was not incorporated in the quantitative guidance we gave in mid-December. While the HIsmelt technology still has promise, the partners had decided that additional capital expenditures would not be a good investment in the current economic environment. For Nucor, we believe our best iron-making investment opportunities today are in growing our direct reduced iron or DRI production abilities. We will continue to build on both the knowledge gained from our highly successful DRI plant in Trinidad and on our long term supplies of attractively priced natural gas. 
Fourth quarter results also included $39 million of pre-operating and startup costs. On a quarterly basis, there has been some improvement from the peak level of more than $50 million in 2010's first quarter. For the full year 2010, these expenses totaled $175 million. Nucor typically incurs significant pre-operating and startup expenses during economic downturns. We view these costs as investments to grow our long-term earnings power. We look for these new businesses to be significant profit generators in the years ahead. That has been our company's experience over many three cycles. 
For example, Nucor's most recent cyclical peak earnings of almost $6 per share in 2008 carried sizable benefits in contributions from the startup projects undertaken during the 2001 to 2003 downturn. It goes back to Dan's point that our team expects to continue Nucor's long history of emerging from downturns stronger than we entered them. Successful execution of this strategy is how we build long-term value for our shareholders. It is our financial strength that allows us to invest in attractive growth opportunities through the economic cycle. At the close of 2010, cash and short-term investments totaled almost $2.5 billion. Not included in that total is an additional $600 million of restricted cash. This restricted cash resulted from our issuance of Gulf Opportunity or GO Zone Bonds in November. These tax-exempt bonds were authorized by the State of Louisiana and will finance a significant portion of the $750 million DRI plant we're building in St. James Parish, Louisiana. 
Further to Nucor's strong liquidity, our $1.3 billion unsecured revolving credit facility is undrawn and does not mature until November 2012. We have no commercial paper outstanding. Long-term debt totaled $4.3 billion at year-end 2010. That is an increase of $1.2 billion from the beginning of the year. Nucor's conservative financial practices and strong balance sheet allowed us to be opportunistic in taking advantage of favorable credit market conditions last year to reduce our overall cost of capital. In addition to November's tax-exempt bond financing, we issued $600 million of 12-year unsecured notes with a coupon rate of 4.125%. That transaction was an excellent opportunity to prepare for upcoming long-term debt maturities of $650 million in 2012 and $250 million in 2013.  Allowing for these dynamics, Moody's has reported that our debt-to-capital ratio will be viewed on a net debt basis for any cash balances over $1.2 billion. At year-end 2010, that net debt-to-capital ratio was approximately 29%. That calculation excludes restricted cash. 
Our operating cash flow performance in 2010 highlights another key strength of our business model. Cash provided by operating activities were nearly $900 million in 2010. That more than covered capital spending of $345 million and cash dividends paid of $457 million for the year. In 2011, we will continue to allocate capital to investments that build our long-term earnings power and provide attractive returns to our shareholders. We project 2011 capital spending of approximately $560 million. Included in that total are about $120 million of spending for our Louisiana DRI plant and about $60 million for our natural gas working interest drilling program. 
As we enter the first quarter, the trend of improving market conditions that began in the fourth quarter has continued. Steel mill utilization rates have increased. In fact, fourth quarter shipments increased 32% over third quarter levels. We have been able to significantly raise mill selling prices in response to rising raw material costs and some improvement in end-use demand. Downstream fabricated Construction Products markets remain very challenging. Overall, we expect a return to profitability in the first quarter, and we believe the positive trend in earnings will continue into the second quarter.  We'll again follow our practice of providing quantitative guidance in the final month of the quarter. 
In the long-term, we are very optimistic about Nucor's prospects to continue building attractive and sustainable long-term value for our shareholders. Our team is working hard and very effectively to capitalize on our company's position of strength. Thank you for your interest in Nucor.
Dan?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. I'll now ask John Ferriola to report on Nucor's operation.
componenttext: Thank you, Jim. I'll now ask John Ferriola to report on Nucor's operation.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. Good afternoon. Let me begin by thanking all of our raw materials, steelmaking and steel products teammates for your outstanding commitment to working safely and taking care of Nucor's customers. We are extremely proud of the work that you ar
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. Good afternoon. Let me begin by thanking all of our raw materials, steelmaking and steel products teammates for your outstanding commitment to working safely and taking care of Nucor's customers. We are extremely proud of the work that you are doing in the tough economic times that have been with us for more than two years. Thank you, and please keep it going.
My report can be summarized in this one sentence: For Nucor, downturns create opportunities; opportunities for profitable growth. Here are some examples of how we are coming out of the economic downturn stronger than we entered it. Nucor's plate and structural mills are doing an excellent job of growing our market during the current downturn. Highlighting the gains, these mills have shipped a total of 240,000 tons of products that were not even offered in our mix two years ago. Even better, their work continues. Our Hertford County, North Carolina plate mills' new heat treat line was commissioned in the fourth quarter of 2010, and it is quickly ramping up to its full capacity of 125,000 tons per year. The product coming off of this line is everything we hoped it would be: Great shape, great surface and right on spec.  This investment allows Hertford County to grow into higher margin products where higher strength, abrasion resistance and greater toughness are required. 
Our Tuscaloosa, Alabama plate mill team has continued to improve our recently added temper line so that it's now capable of running one-inch thick plates. This will allow us to sell as much as 250,000 tons per year of higher margins, temper pass, cut-to-length plates blades rather than commodity hot rolled coil. Just as exciting, the Tuscaloosa team has used their ingenuity and virtually no capital to start producing discrete plate off the end of the hot mill. We expect to be able to produce as much as 125,000 tons per year of this higher valued, higher margin discrete plate at Tuscaloosa due to these improvements.
Although these projects at Hertford County in Tuscaloosa will not increase our total plate capacity, they will have the combined effect of moving more than 500,000 annual tons of plate output from commodity grades to higher value grades that generate higher margins per ton. That, of course, means higher earnings power in the future from our plate mills.  And we will not stop there in expanding our portfolio of margin-enhanced plate products to better serve our customers and generate greater profits for our shareholders.
We recently approved a capital to install a vacuum degasser at Hertford County. Commissioning is expected in the first quarter of 2013. This will further broaden our product mix to include armor plate and certain alloyed plate grades. Our Bar Mill Group is also growing Nucor's long-term earnings power with a number of projects that have started up during the current downturn. These include our new SBQ mill in Memphis and our wire rod and coiled rebar rolling mill in Arizona. The Memphis mill more than doubles our capacity to serve the SBQ mill in Memphis and our wire rod and coil rebar rolling mill in Arizona. The Memphis mill more than doubles our capacity to serve the SBQ markets, while also expanding our product range into the highly attractive 3-inch and 10-inch Larger Diameter segment.  Memphis continues to gain product qualifications and production volumes for OEMs in the construction equipment, automotive, heavy truck, farm equipment and energy markets.  In December, our Memphis team set a record for shipments of rolled finished goods.  With the addition of our low-cost rolling mill in Arizona, Nucor can now serve all regions of the country with our wire rod products. Our Nucor Steel Kingman team also set our shipment record in December and recently expanded from a single shift to double shift operations.
Reflecting our culture's drive for continual improvement and profitable growth, there is more to come. For example, Nucor Steel Nebraska will be adding a downstream processing line that provides new growth opportunities and even higher-quality SBQ products than they currently offer. Additionally, our bar mills in Texas, Utah and South Carolina, along with our Nucor-Yamato beam mill, have established NQA-1 quality systems that will allow them to supply steel to nuclear power plant construction projects.
Nucor's Sheet Mill group is also continuing to move up the value chain, with margin-enhanced products that grow long-term earnings power. Building on Nucor Steel Berkeley's success with value-added vacuum degassed steel, we will be installing a second sheet mill vacuum degasser at our Hickman, Arkansas facility. As the westernmost flat rolled facility in the United States, with a vacuum degasser, Nucor Steel Arkansas will be strategically positioned to take advantage of the growing markets to the West, Southwest and in Mexico. Already, over 20% of all the degassed deals currently sold in the U.S. are purchased by OEMs located in states adjacent to Arkansas.  In addition to the opportunities to expand our current market share with existing customers in automotive, HVAC, and oil country tubular goods, the Hickman degasser will enable us to develop new customers and target markets such as motor laminations, garage doors and lawn and garden.  We expect commissioning took our in the fourth quarter of 2012.
I will close my report with our thoughts on current market conditions. The market environment for our Fabricated Construction Products business continues to be extremely challenged, and it has been for some time. We have been working throughout 2010 to raise prices in each of the industries in which we participate, with varying degrees of success. In addition to seeing some measured success in achieving price increases, we have seen our market share increase strongly in several of our downstream businesses. In our Vulcraft/Verco group, we achieved significant market share increases in both joist and deck in 2010. 
In our Metal Buildings group, we obtained an even greater market share increase. We also signed up a large number of new builders. Builders are the distribution chain in that industry. In Rebar Fabrication, we purchased several small fabricators in the Southeast and another one in Texas.
We want to thank all of our teammates in those businesses for their excellent work in making the best of a very difficult environment. Despite the challenging times, they are unrelenting in demonstrating the Nucor can-do spirit by working safely, working hard and staying focused on continuous improvement.
On the Steelmaking side, we are encouraged by recent signs of some improvement in wheel demand. However, it is difficult to determine how much of the overall increase and apparent demand is driven by steel buyers reacting to increasing raw material and steel prices.  Fortunately, service center inventories through December remain at relatively low levels. It is our belief that wheel demand will continue to grow gradually throughout 2011.
The December AIA Architecture Billings Index suggests non-residential construction activity may start growing again in late 2011.  We view 2011  with cautious optimism, an optimism anchored by our ongoing view that the U.S. economy is likely to experience a gradual recovery due to structural imbalances that must be addressed by our elected officials. In addition, we are keeping more than a watchful eye on imports that continue to have too great a share of the U.S. market at a time when our low-cost domestic industry is still running at only 70% of capacity. We are focused on taking preemptive trade action as a more supportive administration and Congress has shown a willingness to do. But whatever direction the economy takes over the short term, our team is primed and ready to utilize Nucor's position of strength and our extremely flexible business model to continue to generate long-term earnings for our shareholders.
Thank you for your interest in Nucor. Dan?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. There's one loud and clear message coming from these reports from Jim and John. The Nucor team is building long-term value for our shareholders. And we have had a successful record that extends over nearly five decades of doing just that.
componenttext:
Thank you, John. There's one loud and clear message coming from these reports from Jim and John. The Nucor team is building long-term value for our shareholders. And we have had a successful record that extends over nearly five decades of doing just that. It's worthwhile to look at the long-term value we have generated over the last cycle. From the cyclical trough in our stock price reached in September of 2000 when the new executive team started to 2010's closing price, our long-term shareholders enjoyed a more than 7.3x increase in the value of their investment, including dividends, 7.3x. Speaking of dividends, in December, our board increased our regular quarterly cash dividend for the 38th consecutive year. And over the period from 2000 to 2010, Nucor's base dividend has increased approximately tenfold. These returns to our shareholders to growth in our stock price and paying cash dividends have not just happened by accident or by riding a cyclical upturn. They were achieved by building sustainable business that has generated the highest returns on capital in the North American steel industry over that 2000 to 2010 time span, and they reflect our team's unrelenting focus of being effective stewards of our shareholders' valuable capital.  And our long-term focus and approach to managing our business has been constant through this most recent severe recession. Nucor's continued to make substantial investments that position us for our new higher highs and cyclical earnings power once a sustainable economic recovery arrives.
That's exactly what we mean when we say growing strong returning downturns. From 2007  through our expected 2011 capital spending plans, we have invested more than $6 billion of capital, including both capital expenditures and acquisitions. That is a lot of capital that Nucor shareholders will get paid for to attract the returns as they move into the next upcycle. Our team is very optimistic about Nucor's prospects for rewarding our shareholders with attractive long-term returns, just like we've been doing. Why? Because as a team, we're driven to settle for nothing less. 
Finally, I will close with some very exciting news received just today. We have received the final permit for the two 2.5 million tons DRI plants in Louisiana. These facilities will produce high-quality DRI to use at our SBQ plates and sheet mills. Initially, we will build one DRI plant. We plan to expand it to two separate facilities shortly thereafter. These plants will enable us to continue to allow for greater self sufficiency, controlling more of our own raw materials, along with assuring us of high-quality raw material feed. We anticipate starting construction immediately, and we have placed orders for the major equipment items already with our suppliers.  We have an anticipated startup of mid-2013. The Nucor team' is excited to be part of the St. James Parish community in Louisiana and bringing in the type of high-paying jobs that would help make us an integral part in this community. We appreciate all of the help and support that Governor Bobby Jindall and all the others state and local agencies have given to us to help this process come to fruition.  Once again, thank you for your interest in Nucor and we would now be happy to take your questions.

componenttextpreview: So you had a 1% increase third quarter to fourth quarter. So I'm just trying to understand...

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Here's where you're missing the point. You're talking about the usage versus purchase price. So when you say we only saw 1% increase in usage, we had already seen significant increases in the price that we were paying. And it'll just take over a several-m
componenttext: Here's where you're missing the point. You're talking about the usage versus purchase price. So when you say we only saw 1% increase in usage, we had already seen significant increases in the price that we were paying. And it'll just take over a several-month period, it will take that period of time for all the higher price scrap purchases to work through into our actual usage numbers. And in addition, we work very hard to get pricing in our steel products up to keep as close a space as we could to the scrap movement so our raw material price increases will coincide with the finished steel price increases, substantial ones on both parts. And both of those moves should allow our margins to expand from where they have been reported in the fourth quarter. Exact timing of those things, it's not feasible to pinpoint those for you. But as we've stated, you will see that occur throughout the first quarter, and maybe a month, maybe two, lag between the peak in pricing achieved on steel products; probably closer to a month versus the peak in raw material pricing. And as we get into the second quarter, they should in launched and we're foreseeing a fairly stable pricing environment for both raw materials and steel prices as we move through the second quarter.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: If I could, just any other information you have, of course, being a big player in the construction market, hearing some signs of things are starting to stabilize and wanted to get your take on that. What's causing your downstream to perform a little bit b
componenttext: If I could, just any other information you have, of course, being a big player in the construction market, hearing some signs of things are starting to stabilize and wanted to get your take on that. What's causing your downstream to perform a little bit better if that ties in?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: First off, 2010  was actually the year we saw the bottom occur in the downstream construction markets; and it wasn't 2009, it was 2010. And yes, we do believe we have reached the bottom and that we're seeing some positive demand signs, but they're not rap
componenttext: First off, 2010  was actually the year we saw the bottom occur in the downstream construction markets; and it wasn't 2009, it was 2010. And yes, we do believe we have reached the bottom and that we're seeing some positive demand signs, but they're not rapid and they're not large. We have seen some improvements in the architectural index. One of the faults of that index is that it includes all of the architectural activities whether it's domestic or foreign. So you have to be very careful judging the actual uptick in non-res and construction just from the AIA numbers. You have to take into account more factors than that. But indeed, we have seen things improve. We've come off the bottom, but this company has slow, gradual climb. There's really nothing going on out there that's going to change things in a dramatic fashion in the first quarter. But we do expect to see steady improvement throughout the year, and we do expect to see the ability to maintain strong pricing to cover our raw material cost throughout the year.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Moving on, we'll now go to Brian Yu with Citi.
componenttext: Moving on, we'll now go to Brian Yu with Citi.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Dan, my question relates to the Structural business, So when we look at the minority interest charge, the a profit sharing suggests that you're overall profits there are very similar  to 2004  and '05 levels, but backbench, shipments were a lot higher tha
componenttext: Dan, my question relates to the Structural business, So when we look at the minority interest charge, the a profit sharing suggests that you're overall profits there are very similar  to 2004  and '05 levels, but backbench, shipments were a lot higher than it is today. First, can you discuss your first half outlook on structural? I know you commented a little bit earlier in terms of demand, order entry rates. And then anything else you could share with us about what's changed in the structural business that's allowing this level process relative to shipments?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, my comments with respect to the Structural Beam business and the operations at the mills that produce those products aren't any different to what I just shared with Timna and the answer to her question. With respect to what's changed, John Ferriola
componenttext: Well, my comments with respect to the Structural Beam business and the operations at the mills that produce those products aren't any different to what I just shared with Timna and the answer to her question. With respect to what's changed, John Ferriola specifically addressed the fact that our market -- the products that we are marketing today and the higher value-added mix of those products has had a significant positive impact on the earnings. So while we are producing less tons than back in '04, we are producing more higher-margin tons, and that has allowed us to maintain a very good profitability. John, you have any other comments you want to add?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The only other comment I would make is you asked, Brian, about how we see it going forward. We see the structural mark as very stable going forward and we would expect the first half of 2011 to be similar to our performance in 2010. Again, to Dan's point,
componenttext: The only other comment I would make is you asked, Brian, about how we see it going forward. We see the structural mark as very stable going forward and we would expect the first half of 2011 to be similar to our performance in 2010. Again, to Dan's point, with the higher-margin profits although the volumes will be the same, we expect to see higher margins from that business.

componenttext: On the scrap rebate program and on the contracts that are tied to scrap surcharges, we see it immediately. On the CRU, there's usually a delay of about a month before we realize the price increases that would correspond to spot pricing.

componenttext: And my second question is about the Arizona mill. John, you mentioned that you have increased it into two ships. First, I want to understand the product mix. Is there any revolume there? And second is that increase in the ship out of the volume, is that something changing in the West Coast industry in terms of demand or is this you getting market share from some other people?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: First of all, in terms of product, it's wire rod and it's coiled rebar. And in terms of whether we see the market increasing or whether we're gaining market share, I would say our team is doing a great job of gaining market share in that region. Now we mo
componenttext: First of all, in terms of product, it's wire rod and it's coiled rebar. And in terms of whether we see the market increasing or whether we're gaining market share, I would say our team is doing a great job of gaining market share in that region. Now we move in and out of the contract business in the percentages that we have contract versus spot, a lot of it has to do with just the dynamics in the economy and how fast things are changing. And there have been times when we've had 70% contract business,  times we've been at 25% and we usually determine how much that will do by the expected volatility that we see going forward. And right now, the best mix for us is to maintain something at the lower end of our total production in the contract market.

componenttext: We're currently running at 60% of capacity and now we just build upon what you said and add that the Memphis team has done a great job of gaining qualifications from all of those OEMs. It is a long, difficult process and I can tell you that our team there is doing a great job of getting qualified in more and more OEMs and in more and more market segments every  day.

componenttext: This is an operation that really expands the, call it the large end of your SBQ business in a very meaningful way then over the next couple of years, right?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: It absolutely does. When you look at it, working side-by-side with our Nebraska plant, we'll be able to supply SBQ bars from about 1/4 inch up to 10 inches and that's a great span of products to be able to offer to the market.
componenttext: It absolutely does. When you look at it, working side-by-side with our Nebraska plant, we'll be able to supply SBQ bars from about 1/4 inch up to 10 inches and that's a great span of products to be able to offer to the market.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Of course we're also supplying forging quality, semi-finished to the forging industry in very large sizes of blooms and rounds. What's the largest one we're making there now? About 13-inch round. And the other thing to keep in mind there is the quality is
componenttext: Of course we're also supplying forging quality, semi-finished to the forging industry in very large sizes of blooms and rounds. What's the largest one we're making there now? About 13-inch round. And the other thing to keep in mind there is the quality is so, so important. It takes so long to get approved, but once you do get approved you tend to have a very solid customer base that continues to grow with you into new and more products. One of the most satisfying things that I've heard most recently about the quality, being a former metallurgist, is how our customers are basically coming to us saying your quality is as good as the quality we're seeing out of the Japanese and other foreign producers, which is normally regard as the tops of quality in this area. So it's very satisfying to see that our team is really focused on  making the quality products, that customers are giving and opening their eyes wide to the fact that they can do things that they didn't really think we could have done in the domestic market here. So it's a big opportunity for us to continue to grow our customer base in a positive way.

componenttext: I was wondering if you could give us an update on scrap? In the last week and a half, if you've seen the prime end of the scrap market be stable. Has strengthened a little bit? Has it weakened a little bit? And do you think the weather that we're getting on the East Coast could have an impact on the February number as it unfolds here over the next couple of weeks?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me put it to you this way. Nobody in this business, whether on the scrap side, the analyst side or the steel producer user side, predicted what was going to happen with scrap over the last couple of months. And so being that we have such a stellar tra
componenttext: Let me put it to you this way. Nobody in this business, whether on the scrap side, the analyst side or the steel producer user side, predicted what was going to happen with scrap over the last couple of months. And so being that we have such a stellar track record, we're going to refrain from predicting what we think what's going to happen to scrap over the next couple of months.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Dan, what I always say, "The key to good forecasting is to forecast often." So...
componenttext: Dan, what I always say, "The key to good forecasting is to forecast often." So...

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: What I will say is it that there has been a tremendous run up in scrap prices and we do believe that we will see a more stable environment for scrap pricing going forward. Not that it won't have moves up and down, but in general, it'll will be much more s
componenttext: What I will say is it that there has been a tremendous run up in scrap prices and we do believe that we will see a more stable environment for scrap pricing going forward. Not that it won't have moves up and down, but in general, it'll will be much more stable and it will be at these elevated levels. And a lot of our scrap market behavior is dictated by a lot of export that has been growing and growing year after year. And while they're not necessarily real consist  when they come to the market and when they go away from the market so that's added an element of volatility over the past year as prices have gone up. But again, we do see a more stable environment going forward. Whether it goes up $20 or down $20 or what-have-you over the next couple of months, we've seen the lion's share, we believe, of the volatility. Although it's still at risk for that in the future, but right now, we just predict more stable environment going forward.

componenttext: David, typically in these down periods, Nucor has invested heavily in its operations using our strong balance sheet and preparing for the next upturn. And if you go back and listen to all the things that John mentioned that we were doing and plan on doing, you can get a sense for that continued investment and the future in our operations, new products, new markets. And so that's going to continue and as we're dropping projects off or adding new projects so I would expect that you're going to see a continued level of new projects and startup costs to those new projects as we go through the year. Exactly where we end up, I don't know, but they will continue at a pretty good pace

componenttext: Just on the pig iron facility, could you revisit a little bit your iron ore and gas arrangements? Maybe talk a little bit about expected cash cost to production there once it's all done.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: First, the project that we have approved now by the state is direct reduced irons, not pig irons. And you're right, the two variables that go into that are iron ore and natural gas. Natural gas, we'd mentioned in our last call, we have a very good arrange
componenttext: First, the project that we have approved now by the state is direct reduced irons, not pig irons. And you're right, the two variables that go into that are iron ore and natural gas. Natural gas, we'd mentioned in our last call, we have a very good arrangement that keeps natural gas prices at very competitive levels that's comparable to what we've seen over the last 12 months going forward for 20 plus years. We're not going to give you the actual numbers, but I give you a frame of reference there as to where pricing has been in the last 12 months on natural gas. And as far as iron ore goes, we stated that up to this point in time, we'll be spot market, purchases in the open market like we do at our current DRI facility in Trinidad.

componenttext: Currently, the Trinidad operations are mostly outside of the U.S. Canada is the closest we get to be in the U.S., and the rest comes from pretty much Brazil. And we anticipate a similar type of mix going forward for the second and third facilities.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just quickly, you talked a little bit about keeping a close eye on imports. Can you give any update on what you're seeing on that front? We've heard mostly that imports haven't been a problem.
componenttext: And then just quickly, you talked a little bit about keeping a close eye on imports. Can you give any update on what you're seeing on that front? We've heard mostly that imports haven't been a problem.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: "Not a problem" has to be put in quotations. The industry's average operating rate of 70% last year and imports are up some 50%. That makes no sense whatsoever considering how cost competitive we are in the marketplace. There have been trade cases filed b
componenttext: "Not a problem" has to be put in quotations. The industry's average operating rate of 70% last year and imports are up some 50%. That makes no sense whatsoever considering how cost competitive we are in the marketplace. There have been trade cases filed because of some of that, and we are looking and working as we speak filing some proactive cases. The amount of imports coming in are way too high. And you don't see that anywhere else in the world to that level. And the cost for making steel around the world have gone as fast, if not faster than in our domestic market for many of the domestic producers. So we don't believe we're going to see a massive decrease over the levels we've seen, but the levels we've seen is still too high.
