headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan, and good afternoon. Let me begin by thanking all of our raw materials, steelmaking and steel bars team mates for your outstanding commitment to working safely and taking care of Nucor's customers. That commitment was severely tested in the se
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan, and good afternoon. Let me begin by thanking all of our raw materials, steelmaking and steel bars team mates for your outstanding commitment to working safely and taking care of Nucor's customers. That commitment was severely tested in the second quarter with the major challenges presented by weather-related power outages and historic river flooding. Your response to these challenges again demonstrate that Nucor is North America's most reliable steel and steel products producer. Thank you, and keep up the great work. 
The impact of these disruptions is evidenced by the decline in our steel mill capacity utilization. It dropped to 70.7% in the second quarter, which is down from 79.6% in the first quarter. By far, the biggest challenge we faced was from the loss of full electrical power at Alabama sheet mill for 29 days f following the devastating tornadoes that hit that area in late April. 
But understanding our company and how our culture creates long term value, there's a much bigger story than any short-term loss on production, shipments and even earnings. The biggest story is how our team responded to take care of all of our customers during such a challenging period. 
Here's how the Nucor team, the one Nucor team responded. Immediately after power was lost, our dedicated team work with their respective sheet mill divisions to successfully move all the container to all the Nucor sheet mills. Those orders were then produced and delivered on time. And the change in production sourcing within the Nucor sheet mill group was seamless, if not invisible, to our customers. One order from a major world OEM customer, normally supplied by -- was deduced at out our Berkeley, South Carolina mill. It was then sent back into which had restored enough power to run the cold mill to its cold ruling. Following that, it was delivered on time to our customers at Alabama facility, and all of that took place within 11 days. 
There are many other stories similar to this that I could share with you about how the one Nucor team pulled together throughout our company. The bottom line is that we use Nucor's unrivaled position of strength and flexibility to take care of our customers. 
We also consider the community in which we live and work to be our valued customers. In the days immediately following the devastating tornadoes that hit Tuscaloosa, while those mills were without power to operate, our team from those facilities and many other Nucor facilities sprang into action. They worked tirelessly, many on a voluntary basis to assist in the rescue and recovery efforts taking place in those hard-hit communities. Using Nucor supply: Chainsaws, bobcats, generators and other equipment, much of which was sent from other Nucor divisions throughout the country, they proved through the actions Nucor's commitment to being a good stewards of the communities in which we live and work. I have never been more proud of the Nucor culture and of our Nucor team. Thank you all. 
Since 2008, Nucor has invested almost $5 billion of our shoulders valuable capital so that we can take care of our customers. Those investments enable us to take care of our customers with unrivaled operational flexibility, unmatched product diversification and an absolute commitment to always getting the job done. 
As Jim Frias noted, the returns from those investments are becoming more evident even in the current distressed economy. And the beat goes on with a number of major capital projects underway for 2011. 
Raw materials initiatives included our Louisiana directly sign for a DRI plant and our natural gas working interest drilling program. We expect our increased DRI production capacity, combined with control over the necessary supply of reductant, will establish a significant and sustainable competitive advantage to Nucor's steelmaking business. Also, the  David J. Joseph recycling operations are growing their earnings power with the addition of more nonferrous metal recovery capacity. 
On the steelmaking site, we continue to invest on projects that will further expand our product offerings and allow us to move further up to value chain. For example, we are installing gases at both our office in sheet mill and our North Carolina plate mill. 
I will close my report with our thoughts on the current market conditions. Overall, demand is best described as steady. Some markets are even experiencing some increased in real demand. The non-residential and residential construction markets continue to suffer from a recessionary levels of demand. Market improvements are slower at best but importantly, service under inventories remain at relatively low levels. 
Unfortunately, excess supply in the sheet market is pressuring pricing and margins. In addition to new domestic capacity, imports of sheet steel have increased significantly. Year-to-date, through May, imports of hot rolled and cold rolled sheet steel have increased by 18% over a year-ago level and is increased to 1.3 million tons. Unless these supply demand and pricing dynamics reverse themselves, the sheet market will be the most challenging for the entire industry in the third quarter. 
I will also note that we remain very concerned about imports across all product lines. It is important for the U.S. government to vigorously enforce the anti-dumping duty laws. No product line is immune from the negative impact of illegally traded -- of illegal trading, and is important that existing antidumping orders be maintained in the U.S. industry to remain viable. But whatever the direction these economy and the steel market take in the coming months, the Nucor team is prime and ready to grow stronger. 
So one Nucor grows stronger, we position our company for new high highs in cyclical earnings power once a sustainable economic recovery occurs. Our team thank you for your interest in Nucor. Dan?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Our team is excited at Nucor's best is to come. Before I take questions, I would like to emphasize one point in particular. We are encouraged but by no means satisfied with second quarter and 6-month performance. Nucor's annualized return
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Our team is excited at Nucor's best is to come. Before I take questions, I would like to emphasize one point in particular. We are encouraged but by no means satisfied with second quarter and 6-month performance. Nucor's annualized return equity to this first have exceeds 12%. This is achieved with the lowest financial leverage in the industry. We'll continue to put those strengths to work for us regardless of what direction the economy takes to be an industry leader in profitability and performance. 
At this time, we would like to take your questions.

So if you're asking me fourth quarter can be better than third quarter, demand is going to but significantly first to see that kind of performance going forward that will be better with what we've seen in the second quarter. John, you want to add to that?

componenttextpreview: When you say flatroll, I don't put plates in flatrolls. Typically, we refer to sheet in the vernacular of the industry. On the plate side, we have a different story. We believe that there'll be tremendous energy development and infrastructure development
componenttext: When you say flatroll, I don't put plates in flatrolls. Typically, we refer to sheet in the vernacular of the industry. On the plate side, we have a different story. We believe that there'll be tremendous energy development and infrastructure development coming in the future at some point. It would've been 2 years ago. But it's got to come. There's issues that just have to be dealt with regard as it was in the office. We believe they will get dealt with, and we believe that, that bodes well for the plate market in the future, past what's going on now which is a very healthy plate market. And we continue to see that being healthy through the rest of the year. But we do believe that the opportunity, it has to expand our existing plate operations with additional heat treat facilities. We are going to be putting a normalizing facility in addition to the at Hartford. We're exploring doing something similar in Tuscaloosa, and we are actively engaged in new plate mill location and to serve the market better as we see the growth improving going forward. But it will be in all markets that are strong today. In particular, the energy markets we see being one will be strong. Infrastructure market, it will be strong. And also the heavy equipment markets that we continue to see particularly with companies like Caterpillar starting to move some more into production in the United States from overseas.

componenttext: My question is really on cost and the utilization rate. Can you just talk about where utilization is today and how much you've been able to bounce back from that 71% level? Maybe just talk about the July run rate so far are. And then from a cost standpoint, clearly, you were impacted a bit in the quarter with a lower mix of sheet. Do you get a costs improvement in the third quarter? Assuming that, that sheet mix bumps back up? Can you just talk about how you see assuming flat scrap costs, how the rest of your cost mix will change from 2Q to 3Q?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, a couple of questions there. I'll answer the last one first. Certainly, if you are in a position to be able to recover the lost volume due to weather-related issues and get more facility, your production costs improve dramatically. Partic
componenttext: Well, certainly, a couple of questions there. I'll answer the last one first. Certainly, if you are in a position to be able to recover the lost volume due to weather-related issues and get more facility, your production costs improve dramatically. Particularly at the mill that was influenced most by the huge power outages that hit the Southeast, which was Alabama plant, which is down better part 5 weeks, I think 29, 30 days. And we lost a few also with our Tuscaloosa plate mill. We also had some impacts on shipping and raw material because of a clouding on the Mississippi that impacted not only some is the most but also some of our scrapyards. So anytime you can see that type of reversal and in a core net assuming weather patterns don't. We appear on a similar nature. They should have a positive impact on our cost structure. Having said that, at the end of the day, the strength of the market will dictate whether or not we're able to achieve those recoveries in volume or what exactly, what volumes we will see. We do see, as we already mentioned, a much more competitive environment going into the third quarter on sheet. And while we plan on bidding extremely competitor and not losing volume, whether or not there's additional volume to be gained is another matter. One other thing is that we do probably benefits from is the fact that the lead times are relatively short. With the publish, I'm not going to quote what our lead times are, but the industry's lead times are fairly well-known on the sheet side. And the scrap markets often, and that profit will pass through middle in the third quarter. And if there's any relief on pricing during the third quarter, that should flow through fairly quickly as well. But those are the potential positives. Right now, we are very cautious about outlook on the flatroll business for the third quarter. John, do you have anything you wan add?

You mentioned coming back the teams at Tuscaloosa and, I want to take the opportunity to thank those teams for the weather they did recovery that came back on line well, safely and with the normal high quality and I just wanted to say thank you the teams at both of those divisions and all of our other teammates went down to get on those back weekly and safely.

componenttext: First question had to deal with your SPQ expansion in Memphis. Are you able to give us a sense of how much capacity you have now you've built that facility? And also, I've been reading about maybe looking at adding a forecast there and doing some other expansions at the Darlington. And can you give us some sense of what your ultimate target capacity is for as SPQ?

componenttext: I'm going to ask John to speak to that. Currently, the rate of capacity at that facility is somewhere around 850,000 tons, but that rate of capacity is by a rate of capacity is in time exceeded the normal continuous improvement of our operations. And we are not -- we're looking at putting a forward strand on the cash, not the -- unless I've been left out of the loop. So John?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me confirm that is definitely a stream, okay. it's not a forecaster. But it will increase our capacity at the Memphis mill about 30% to 35%. And we plan to grow that business as we continue to move in for the more evaluated products, and we begin -- w
componenttext: Let me confirm that is definitely a stream, okay. it's not a forecaster. But it will increase our capacity at the Memphis mill about 30% to 35%. And we plan to grow that business as we continue to move in for the more evaluated products, and we begin -- we continue to get qualified in evaluated customer base. So the team at Memphis demographic has been doing great job in getting qualified, a quality out of the Memphis facility has been outstanding. And that facility compliments of our Nebraska facility, which allows us to offer the widest breadth of products and sizes to the SPQ market in North America. So we feel very confident about the SPQ market going forward.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011

componenttext: Dan, in the supplemental information, it shows volume decline from sheet and structural but these were also products that had the greater sequential average price improvement. And I was wondering if there was some rationalization in order book during the quarter to about mix that helps explain outsize price moves?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, on the sheet side of the business, I think we pretty well discuss that and answer that question already. And the volume losses principally are due to the outages at mill that does over 200,000 tons a month. And it was down for about a month. But the
componenttext: Well, on the sheet side of the business, I think we pretty well discuss that and answer that question already. And the volume losses principally are due to the outages at mill that does over 200,000 tons a month. And it was down for about a month. But the pricing we also addressed as we saw pricing increases during the quarter that overcame the raw material increases. On the beam side of the business, I think there's a good argument to be made that the product diversity that we had in that business really help to our margins even though the lines are down slightly. Structural also have a big impact. The mix other products produced during the quarter also had a big impact on that.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011

componenttext: Can you go into detail just about that excite where we talk about in terms sustainability going forward relative to what you're seeing in the non-res markets?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the sustainability going forward is strong, the ability to sustain that is strong because of the wide product mix that we have on our beam mills, nobody in the U.S. makes the wide range for really heavy weights to the lightest weights to all variety
componenttext: Well, the sustainability going forward is strong, the ability to sustain that is strong because of the wide product mix that we have on our beam mills, nobody in the U.S. makes the wide range for really heavy weights to the lightest weights to all variety of different products that we make in the side of things. John, do you want to add anything to that?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I agree, Dan. The product diversity really allows us to sustain any product mix scenario. But really drives the product is from month to month, quarter to quarter, is a type of product that's going out of the market is not so much anything we do on th
componenttext: No, I agree, Dan. The product diversity really allows us to sustain any product mix scenario. But really drives the product is from month to month, quarter to quarter, is a type of product that's going out of the market is not so much anything we do on the marketing perspective. So it's really demand-driven, and that's very hard for us to predict. We do have the ability to sustain it, as Dan mentioned, no matter which direction it goes, but a product mix is more project-dependent.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions if I could. One is just simply looking at the price average realization in your sheet business first to second quarter relative to what we calculated to be the spot market. The first quarter was a pretty big discount. The second quarter
componenttext: I have 2 questions if I could. One is just simply looking at the price average realization in your sheet business first to second quarter relative to what we calculated to be the spot market. The first quarter was a pretty big discount. The second quarter was a baby premium. Just wondering if you could help you understand what that might have been some big difference. I know you're doing more value add, but it looks like $120 swing. Is there anything else I might be missing there?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: The other factor that plays into it would be the contract pricing. We have about 35% to 40% of our sheet business is based upon contract pricing. Some of which is based on quarterly CRU numbers. So, of course, the pricing of the first quarter was based up
componenttext: The other factor that plays into it would be the contract pricing. We have about 35% to 40% of our sheet business is based upon contract pricing. Some of which is based on quarterly CRU numbers. So, of course, the pricing of the first quarter was based upon fourth quarter of last year CRU average pricing. In the second quarter, we benefited from the higher CRU pricing in the first quarter.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011

componenttext: And so it would not also help into the third quarter or how do we think about that?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: The other question I had is again in light of the sheet oversupply problems you talked about, have you thought about, and I think you addressed a little bit containing production. Is there a way to think about exports, at what price are at what -- how do
componenttext: The other question I had is again in light of the sheet oversupply problems you talked about, have you thought about, and I think you addressed a little bit containing production. Is there a way to think about exports, at what price are at what -- how do you think about export market as a potential way to just oversupply in the sheet market?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, our way to adjust any oversupply situation is to be extremely competitive and be successful based upon our core structures and our customer service and quality and the product range we have. As far as exports go, regardless of what's going on in the
componenttext: Well, our way to adjust any oversupply situation is to be extremely competitive and be successful based upon our core structures and our customer service and quality and the product range we have. As far as exports go, regardless of what's going on in the domestic market, we are active on the export front, always looking for opportunities. And particularly in a without the additional capacity coming on stream, the industry is not running at full capacity. So it's been a long-term focus of ours to grow exports. We're working on that and exporting quite significantly '06, '07, '08, and it continues through this downturn as well. So it's not something that I would say that all focus on because of domestic overcapacity. That would be my being competitive as possible to get as much business as we can bring into our operations.

componenttextpreview: Just to one question on the SBQ market. It seems to be very tight here. Some products are up close to the end of 2012 at this point. And I just wanted to get your opinion on what the demand for this market, it looks like longer term? I know there's been a
componenttext: Just to one question on the SBQ market. It seems to be very tight here. Some products are up close to the end of 2012 at this point. And I just wanted to get your opinion on what the demand for this market, it looks like longer term? I know there's been about 1 million tons kind of knocked off-line by Republic. But the same time, you're seeing a lot of restarts, Memphis and some others. Kind of offsetting that and certainly the economy is not running at full speed here. We're not nowhere near 16 million build. So what's really driving the tightness in that market and something structural change on the demand side?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's principally -- our automotive has uptick compared to a year ago without a doubt. This way below its peak, no doubt there either. But I think the agricultural sectors, the heavy equipment sectors, the customers like Caterpillar and John Deere, and so
componenttext: It's principally -- our automotive has uptick compared to a year ago without a doubt. This way below its peak, no doubt there either. But I think the agricultural sectors, the heavy equipment sectors, the customers like Caterpillar and John Deere, and so on, that's where a lot of demand is coming from and will continue to come from.

componenttext: Any suggestion that is localized is pure. We have 1.3 million tons of lateral steel coming into United States every direction in the world. So you put that into perspective with whether or not the excess capacity is coming from on Pennsylvania or Alabama or Mississippi, it's immaterial. Everybody feels the pressure of additional capacity coming to the U.S. market, whether it be domestic or import. And to get so by everybody. There's nobody from it by any stretch of the imagination and if you take a look at history you find it to be extremely true.

It doesn't take very long for it to shakeout. It's impacting all the players.

componenttext: Well, first off, as John mentioned in his remarks, our view of pricing at this point in time is that near bottom on collateral, but that's our best guess. There's been a significant drop off in pricing, about $190 a ton. And in the publish market place, this is not our numbers. It's the publish marketplace numbers. And I guess you should ask folks after it whether they want to continue whether they want to make any money to what they did eight or continue to lose money.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our view has always been there were lousy forecasters what's going to happen how the raw material side, but I would say that under current conditions, we don't see any severe upward pressure. Maybe some slight downward pressure, but pretty much flat as we
componenttext: Our view has always been there were lousy forecasters what's going to happen how the raw material side, but I would say that under current conditions, we don't see any severe upward pressure. Maybe some slight downward pressure, but pretty much flat as we go forward. But, like I said earlier, there any decreases in raw materials costs that will pass through to the third quarter for virtually everybody. In the -- forward stock the inventory. And likewise, on pricing any pricing improvements will go through pretty quickly into the third quarter because of the overall lead times in the industry.

componenttext: I think for the most part, nonresidential construction multi-apartments, there are some slight improvements in activity there. But nothing that we quantify been strong by any stretch of the imagination. But you've seen some numbers recently, where multi-family dwellings are up 30% compared to previous time periods. We're seeing some infrastructure activity than nothing of any major that is needed in this country. It's just a general fact that we hit the bottom, and there was no else to go but up, and so we start to see just gradual increases in activity.

componenttext: No, but it's just like to see what appears to be somewhat selection to, however tough and modest but at least it's a beginning, so that's encouraging. Another thing, I was just about the others earlier this weak, one of your competitors have indicated some thoughts about potential for sheet pricing to show inflection and moving up. If you look at the futures markets, they've moved actually off the bottom here just in the last week. And the the futures prices for moving into the first half are a lot stronger than they are in the fourth quarter also the differential between U.S. pricing and Chinese, the Shanghai export prices, what I would characterize as an unsustainably low level indicated some operable mats of opportunity for U.S. sheet pricing. Is there any color that you can give in terms of your own opinion on when you think some pricing inflection might unfold here?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we've already made the comments that we feel like the pricing is at or near bottom, so going up or greater than going down. But you can't get away from the fact that the weather overseas bringing on additional capacity in access demand or new capa
componenttext: I think we've already made the comments that we feel like the pricing is at or near bottom, so going up or greater than going down. But you can't get away from the fact that the weather overseas bringing on additional capacity in access demand or new capacity coming on stream domestically. That's an issue that has to be dealt with. It can't be ignored. It's real, and it will have an impact what exactly what strengthening takes place in the quarter and people are going to David Amar to please. Everybody's out there trying to do further companies what they can do to be more profitable and bring more volume. So I continue to believe, we continue to believe this is going to be a very competitive marketplace.

componenttext: The impact was in loss volume. And so, I mean, you imagine keeping all your treatments employed and actually helping out in the communities were paying them for their efforts to salvage homes, safe people were buried under stuff and trees and houses, you name it. But you're not producing any steel. This a major cost impact. We did layer of folks out we kept them busy. And there was a significant impact maybe not on existing orders on the books. We moved them very well to other operations to fill those orders. But when you're sitting there you're telling customers while that DBAs telling us 3 or 5 weeks, you probably not going to get kind of order entry that you're going to need to build to order book at that location going forward. So across it's difficult. We basically lost a little over a month production at that facility, 50,000 tons a week or more.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Nucor Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. Certain statements made during this conference call will be forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. The words w
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Nucor Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. Certain statements made during this conference call will be forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. The words we expect, believe, anticipate and variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify those forward-looking statements, which are based on management's current expectations and information that is currently available.  Although Nucor believes they are based on reasonable assumptions, there can be no assurance that future events will not affect their accuracy. 
More information about the risks and uncertainties relating to these forward-looking statements may be found in the Nucor's latest 10-K and subsequently filed 10-Qs, which are available on the SEC's and Nucor's website. The forward-looking statements made in this conference call speak only as of this date, and Nucor does not assume any obligation to update them either as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
Now for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Dan DiMicco, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Nucor Corporation. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Marissa. Good afternoon. This is Dan DiMicco, Nucor's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. Thank you for joining us on our conference call and as always, we appreciate your interest in Nucor. With me for today's call are the other members of
componenttext:
Thank you, Marissa. Good afternoon. This is Dan DiMicco, Nucor's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. Thank you for joining us on our conference call and as always, we appreciate your interest in Nucor. 
With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor's senior management team, our President and Chief Operating Officer, John Ferriola; our Chief Financial Officer, Jim Frias; and our other Executive Vice Presidents, Jim Darsey, over our Long Products group; Keith Grass, over our Raw Materials group; Ladd Hall, over our Flat-rolled and Direct Reduced Iron group; Ham Lott, over our Fabricated Products group; and Joe Stratman, who heads up our Business Development group, as well as our Beam and Plate business. 
First, and most importantly, I want to thank everyone in our team at Nucor and our Harris Steel and David J. Joseph operations for working safely, working hard and working together. And the quarter marked by historically weak construction markets and severe weather issues have impacted a number of our facilities, but you delivered impressive results to our customers and to our shareholders. The talent, dedication and can-do attitude that the Nucor team brings to work each day is and always will be our company's greatest competitive advantage. Thank you. 
The second quarter 2011 earnings of $0.94 per diluted share were nearly double first quarter earnings of $0.50 per share, and more than triple the year-ago second quarter earnings of $0.29 per share. We are certainly encouraged by this performance, and especially the continued solid profitability of our combined construction products offerings from our Long Products, Steel Mills and Downstream Fabrication businesses. These results reinforce our conviction as to the powerful earnings leverage we will see ahead of us once the sustainable economic recovery never begins. 
Our second quarter results also highlight Nucor's position of strength in North America and the steel industry. We have a business model that is built around operational flexibility, product diversification, market leadership positions, financial strength and most importantly, our unique culture.  The competitive advantages I've just described allowed new quarter profit in a good way to both our core Construction Product businesses and from the pockets of strength found in the still depressed economy. Additionally, some of our major growth initiatives undertaken during the current economic downturn are beginning to contribute to Nucor's earnings. Our Sheet Mills benefited from an upturn in pricing that began last winter and peaked this spring. 
We also experienced steady to improving demand in several important end-use markets such as energy, transportation, water heaters, and HVAC. And there was a strong contribution from the new higher value-added products that our sheet mill teams have penetrated in a good way. Our plate mills capitalized on both improved pricing and solid demand from a number of sectors, including heavy equipment, truck trailers, energy, mining and rail, and our recent product expansion to each we play continued to pay off in a good way. 
Our SBQ, our special bar quality mills, including our newest, Memphis, benefited from an extremely tight SBQ market. Our SBQs have been and will continue to be successful in growing its coil product range and market penetration. Our downstream Cold Finished Bar and Fastener businesses achieved strong profitability in the just completed quarter, and Long Products mills are competing in very depressed construction markets. They, nevertheless, began to deliver solid profits for the second quarter and first half of this year. The coiled rebar mills and beam mills continued to benefit from the market leadership positions and low cost production to unravel the breadth of product offering, which are complemented by our fabricated construction products and their coast-to-coast distribution capability. 
Quite frankly, when I review our second quarter and first half performance, I am very perplexed by how some financial market participants are so quick to claim that Nucor will underperform its steel industry peers due to our company's heavy participation in construction markets. Our results for the second quarter and over many economic cycles tell a very different story. Again, the future of our performance and most importantly, our ability to reward our shareholders is the flexibility, diversification and sustainability found in our business model. Even better, our business model allows us to focus on the long term and grow stronger during downturns, such as what continues to face the U.S. economy today.  Recent economic data are clear. The U.S. economy is still struggling to emerge from the great recession, and unable to move to a path of vibrant and sustainable growth. 
In June, the real or U-6 unemployment rate increased to 16.2% from 15.8% in May. Going back to March of this year, the number of unemployed people has increased by 545,000. And today's job numbers were no more encouraging. Meanwhile, the U.S. trade deficit widened over $50 billion in May, its highest level in more than 2.5 years. GDP growth for this year's first half is an abysmal rate of less than 2%.  This economic performance, or lack thereof, is not surprising. Our nation has failed to implement real solutions to eliminate the unsustainable structural imbalances that are dragging our economy deeper and deeper into a hole of little or no growth and extreme debt. 
As our team have stated in our previous calls and many other forms, the way forward through a stronger and more sustainable American economy is straightforward. Our leaders need to focus on real solutions that eliminate the structural imbalances and at the same time, create where economy needs most, jobs, jobs and more jobs. This could be accomplished through our 3-point plan to achieve new energy independence, enforce rules-based free trade and thereby, revitalize U.S-based manufacturing and rebuild our company infrastructure. These steps, along with the more competitive global tax system, spending on unraveling of the massive volume of new regulations of a strangling economic growth will lead to a significantly stronger economy, and provide the tax revenues needed to reduce our national debt, and still provide for those commitments made by our government to the American people. No other solution will accomplish this, and create the 25 to 30 million new jobs we need over the next 5 to 10 years. It is time to stop fiddling and to start doing the right things. 
The course of the overall economy and the steel market conditions are barely beyond our control. However, one thing is for certain and under our control. The Nucor team will meet any and all challenges head-on, and turn them into opportunities. This is exactly what our team has been doing for more than 4 decades. 
At this time, I would now ask our CFO, Jim Frias, to discuss our second quarter results. Following Jim's comments, President and COO, John Ferriola, will report on our operations and interpretation of our growth initiatives. Jim?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan, and good afternoon. The second quarter 2011 earnings of $0.94 per diluted share exceeded our guidance range of $0.75 to $0.80 per share. Our results benefited from a stronger-than-expected increase in steel-making metal margins. In the second
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan, and good afternoon. The second quarter 2011 earnings of $0.94 per diluted share exceeded our guidance range of $0.75 to $0.80 per share. Our results benefited from a stronger-than-expected increase in steel-making metal margins. In the second quarter, the metal margin expanded to $447 per ton, a gain of $82 per ton from the first quarter, and an increase of $127 per ton from the trough reached in last year's fourth quarter. This is consistent with the long established historical experience of our steel mills, where rising scrap prices lead after a short lag to higher metal margins. 
Our downstream fabricated construction products continued to operate in very depressed markets. Despite these difficult market conditions, metal margins improved at our Bar and Beam mills as our competitive strengths overcame the effects of relatively low utilization rates. As Dan noted, we continue to generate solid profits in our combined Steel and Fabricated Construction Products businesses. 
In the second quarter, Nucor recorded a LIFO inventory charge of $32 million. That was in line with our first quarter LIFO charge of $31 million. Second quarter results also included $31 million of pre-operating and startup costs. That compares to first quarter cost of $128 million and $43 million in the prior year second quarter. 
Nucor's financial strength allowed us to invest in attractive growth opportunities through the economic cycle -- okay, I'm sorry let me restate that. That compares to first quarter cost of $28 million and $43 million in the prior-year second quarter, and that's speaking to pre-operating and startup costs.  Nucor's financial strength allows us to invest in attractive growth opportunities through the economic cycle. We view pre-operating startup costs as investments to grow our long-term earnings power. For example, the investments made during the current downturn in our Memphis SBQ mill, and our Kingman, Arizona wire rod mill contributed to Nucor's improved profits in the second quarter and first half of this year. 
The second quarter effective tax rate, measured as a percent of earnings before income taxes and non-controlling interest, was 32.6%. However, after adjusting our profits belonging to our non-controlling interest business partners, the effective tax rate increases to 34.2%. 
Earnings per diluted share of $1.44 for the first half of 2011 represent a significant improvement of almost 4x from a year ago's earnings per share of $0.38. Nucor's annualized return on equity through this year's first half exceeds 12%. The Nucor team is achieving this performance in a marketplace where non-residential construction square footage for 2011 is forecasted to be 60% below the peak level reached in 2007.  This return on equity performance is also achieved at the lowest financial leverage in the industry. We're excited by the opportunities ahead to deliver higher returns when the inevitable cyclical recovery finally arrives.  At the close of the second quarter, cash and short term investments totaled $2.3 billion. In addition to that total, we hold $577 million of restricted cash on our balance sheet. The restricted cash is there to fund a significant portion of the $750 million deal iron plant we are building in Louisiana.  Our healthy level of cash and short-term investments will also allow us to repay long-term debt maturities of $650 million in 2012 and $250 million in 2013. 
Further to Nucor's strong liquidity, our $1.3 billion unsecured revolving credit facility is undrawn, and does not mature until November 2012. We have no commercial paper outstanding.  Long-term debt totaled $4.3 billion at the end of the second quarter for a gross debt-to-capital ratio of 36%. Moody's has reported that our debt-to-capital ratio will be viewed on a net debt basis for any cash and short-term investments balance over $1.2 billion. Using that methodology, our net debt-to-capital ratio is 30%, and that calculation excludes the restricted cash. 
Standard & Poor's, in its July 1 report entitled U.S. and Canadian Metals and Mining Companies Strongest to Weakest again ranked Nucor #1 for credit rating and credit outlook among the universe of 61 companies. Nucor was the only metals and mining company in the group that S&P awarded a strong business risk profile due to our competitive position and profit performance relative to our peers.  In 2011, we are continuing to invest in projects that will grow our long-term earnings power and provide attractive returns to our shareholders. We project 2011 capital spending of approximately $500 million. John Ferriola will give you an overview of our capital projects in his remarks. 
Our outlook for the third quarter is tampered by the impacted of new domestic supply and increased imports in the sheet market. For that reason, we expect third quarter earnings to be lower than the second quarter.  Overall demand in end-use market such as automotive, energy, heavy equipment and general manufacturing remain relatively strong. Those markets mainly benefit our special bar quality sheet and plate mills. The markets for downstream fabricated construction products remained challenging, but are slowly improving. Nucor will again follow our practice of providing quantitative guidance around the middle of the final month of the quarter. 
We are very optimistic by Nucor's ability to continue building attractive and sustainable long-term value for our shareholders. We are confident that our team has the right people and the right business model to get the job done. Thank you for your interest in Nucor. Dan?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. Now I'll ask John Ferriola to report on Nucor's operations.
componenttext: Thank you, Jim. Now I'll ask John Ferriola to report on Nucor's operations.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan, and good afternoon. Let me begin by thanking all of our raw materials, steelmaking and steel bar teammates for your outstanding commitment to working safely, and of taking care of Nucor's customers. That commitment was severely tested in the
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan, and good afternoon. Let me begin by thanking all of our raw materials, steelmaking and steel bar teammates for your outstanding commitment to working safely, and of taking care of Nucor's customers. That commitment was severely tested in the second quarter, with the major challenges presented by weather-related power outages and historic river flooding. Your response to these challenges again demonstrate that Nucor is North America's most reliable steel and steel products producer. Thank you, and keep up the great work. 
The impact of these disruptions is evidenced by the decline in our steel mill capacity utilization. It dropped to 70.7% in the second quarter, which is down from 79.6% in the first quarter. By far, the biggest challenge we faced was from the loss of full electrical power at our Decatur, Alabama sheet mill for 29 days, following the devastating tornadoes that hit that area in late April. But in understanding our company and how our culture creates long term value, there's a much bigger story than any short-term loss on production, shipments and even earnings. The biggest story is how our team responded to take care of all of our customers during such a challenging period.  Here's how the Nucor team, the one Nucor team responded. Immediately, after the power was lost, our Decatur team worked with their sister Sheet mill divisions to successfully move all of Decatur's orders to other Nucor sheet mills. Those orders were then produced and delivered on time. And the change in production sourcing within the Nucor sheet mill group was seamless, if not, invisible, to our customers.  One order from a major coal railroad OEM customer, normally supplied by Decatur, was reduced out of hot-rolled coil at out our Berkeley, South Carolina mill. It was then sent back to Decatur, which had restored enough power to run the cold mill for its cold rolling. Following that, it was delivered on time to our customers in Alabama facility, and all of that took place within 11 days.  There are many other stories similar to this that I could share with you about how the one Nucor team hold together throughout our company. The bottom line is that we use Nucor's unrivaled position of strength and flexibility to take care of our customers. 
We also consider the communities in which we live and work to be our valued customers. In the days, immediately following the devastating tornadoes that hit Decatur and Tuscaloosa, while those mills were without power to operate, our teammates from those facilities and many other Nucor facilities sprang into action. They worked tirelessly, many on a voluntary basis to assist in the rescue and recovery efforts taking place in those hard-hit communities, using Nucor-supplied chainsaws, bobcats, generators and other equipment, much of which was sent from other Nucor divisions throughout the country. They proved through their actions Nucor's commitment to being a good steward of the communities in which we live and work. I have never been more proud of the Nucor culture and of our Nucor team. Thank you all. 
Since 2008, Nucor has invested over $5 billion of our shareholder's valuable capital, so that we can take care of our customers. Those investments enable us to take care of our customers with unrivaled operational flexibility, unmatched product diversification and an absolute commitment to always getting the job done.  As Jim Frias noted, the returns from those investments are becoming more evident even in the current distressed economy. And the beat goes on with a number of major capital projects underway for 2011. 
Raw materials initiatives, included our Louisiana  direct-reduced iron or our DRI plant, and our natural gas working interest drilling program. We expect our increased DRI production capacity, combined with control over the necessary supply of reductant, will establish a significant and sustainable competitive advantage to Nucor's steelmaking business. Also, the David J. Joseph recycling operations are growing their earnings power, with the addition of more non-ferrous metal recovery capacity.  On the steelmaking site, we continue to invest in projects that will further expand our product offerings, and allow us to move further up the value chain. For example, we are installing vacuum degassers at both our office on our sheet mill and our North Carolina plate mill. 
I will close my report with our thoughts on the current market conditions. Overall, demand is best described as steady. Some markets are even experiencing some increase in real demand. The non-residential and residential construction markets continue to suffer from recessionary levels of demand. Market improvements are slow at best but importantly, service under inventories remain at relatively low levels. 
Unfortunately, excess supply in the sheet market is pressuring pricing and margins. In addition to new domestic capacity, imports of sheet steel have increased significantly. Year-to-date, through May, imports of hot-rolled and cold-rolled sheet steel have increased by 18% over year-ago level, and is increased to 1.3 million tons. Unless these supply demand and pricing dynamics reverse themselves, the sheet market will be the most challenging for the entire industry in the third quarter. 
I will also note that we remain very concerned about imports across all product lines. It is important for the U.S. government to vigorously enforce the anti-dumping and countervailing duty laws. No product line is immune from the negative impact of illegally traded -- of illegal trading, and it is important that existing anti-dumping orders be maintained in the U.S. industry to remain viable. But whatever direction the economy and the steel market take in the coming months, the Nucor team is prime and ready to grow stronger.  So when Nucor grows stronger, we position our company for new high highs in cyclical earnings power once a sustainable economic recovery occurs. Our team thank you for your interest in Nucor. Dan?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Our team is excited at Nucor's best is yet to come. Before I take questions, I would like to emphasize one point in particular. We are encouraged, but by no means, satisfied with second quarter and 6-month performance. Nucor's annualized
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Our team is excited at Nucor's best is yet to come. Before I take questions, I would like to emphasize one point in particular. We are encouraged, but by no means, satisfied with second quarter and 6-month performance. Nucor's annualized return on equity through this first half exceeds 12%. This is achieved with the lowest financial leverage in the industry. We'll continue to put those strengths to work for us regardless of what direction the economy takes to be an industry leader in profitability and performance. 
At this time, we would like to take your questions.

componenttext: Well, the short-term and the long-term view will both be impacted by the relative demand to supply balance that exist. It doesn't exist in the equation whether it be through imports, excess of imports, so when we balance out or excessive new capacity coming on stream without any of it being kind of taken out.  So if you're asking me, geez, is fourth quarter going to better than third quarter, demand has got to improve significantly for us see the kind of performance going forward that will be better that what we've seen in the second quarter. John, you want to add to that?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think that covers it pretty well. As you know, Michelle, the Sheet business, the sheet market pricing peaked early in the second quarter, and has dropped dramatically throughout the quarter. We see that -- I mean, I believe that -- we believe that we're
componenttext: I think that covers it pretty well. As you know, Michelle, the Sheet business, the sheet market pricing peaked early in the second quarter, and has dropped dramatically throughout the quarter. We see that -- I mean, I believe that -- we believe that we're either at the bottom or close to the bottom of that pricing, but we expect it to bump along at the bottom for quite sometime until we see some significant change in the demand-supply ratio.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, I didn't mean third or fourth quarter. I meant longer term. You've talked about building a plate mill, and so I'd like to get a little bit more color on where you think that market might be and why you might think that that's an opportunity no
componenttext: Okay. Well, I didn't mean third or fourth quarter. I meant longer term. You've talked about building a plate mill, and so I'd like to get a little bit more color on where you think that market might be and why you might think that that's an opportunity not this year, obviously, but longer term?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011

componenttext: I apologize for not asking it right.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
