componenttext: Dan, in the supplemental information, it shows volume declines in sheet and structural but these were also sold products that had the greatest sequential average price improvement. And I was wondering if there was some rationalization of your order book during the quarter to drive up mix that helps explain sort of this out-sized price moves?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, on the Sheet side of the business, I think we’ve pretty well discussed that, and answered that question already. And the volume losses principally are due to the outages at the mill that does over 200,000 tons a month, and was down for better than
componenttext: Well, on the Sheet side of the business, I think we’ve pretty well discussed that, and answered that question already. And the volume losses principally are due to the outages at the mill that does over 200,000 tons a month, and was down for better than a month. But the pricing we've also addressed, as we saw pricing increases during the quarter that overcame the raw material increases. On the Beam side of the business, I think there is a good argument to be made that the product diversity that we have in that business really helped to keep our margins even though the volumes were down slightly. Mix, switch and mix and structural also had a big impact. The mix of the products produced during the quarter also had a big impact on that.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you go into detail just about the mix side, and what are we talking about and then in terms of sustainability going forward relative to what you're seeing in the non-resi markets?
componenttext: Can you go into detail just about the mix side, and what are we talking about and then in terms of sustainability going forward relative to what you're seeing in the non-resi markets?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, sustainability going forward is strong. The ability to sustain that is strong because of the wide product mix that we have on our Beam mills. Nobody in the U.S. makes the wide range from the really heavy foot weights to the lightest foot weights to
componenttext: Well, sustainability going forward is strong. The ability to sustain that is strong because of the wide product mix that we have on our Beam mills. Nobody in the U.S. makes the wide range from the really heavy foot weights to the lightest foot weights to all the variety of different products that we make in the structural side of things. Joe, do you want to add anything to that?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I agree, Dan, that the product diversity really allows us to sustain through any product mix scenario. But what really drives the product mix from month to month, quarter to quarter, is the type of project that's going on in the marketplace, not so much a
componenttext: I agree, Dan, that the product diversity really allows us to sustain through any product mix scenario. But what really drives the product mix from month to month, quarter to quarter, is the type of project that's going on in the marketplace, not so much anything we do on a marketing perspective. So it's really demand-driven, and that's very hard for us to predict. We do have the ability to sustain it, as Dan mentioned, no matter which direction it goes, but the product mix is more project-dependent.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Timna Tanners from Bank of America, Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Timna Tanners from Bank of America, Merrill Lynch.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions if I could. One is just simply looking at the price -- the average price realization in your Sheet business, first to second quarter, relative to what we calculate to be the spot market. The first quarter was a pretty big discount, and
componenttext: I have 2 questions if I could. One is just simply looking at the price -- the average price realization in your Sheet business, first to second quarter, relative to what we calculate to be the spot market. The first quarter was a pretty big discount, and the second quarter was a pretty big premium. Just wondering if you could help me understand what -- if there might have been some big difference? I know you're doing more value add, but it looks like $120 swing. Is there anything else I might be missing there?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: The other factor that plays into it would be the contract pricing. We have about 35% to 40% of our Sheet business is based upon contract pricing, some of which is based on quarterly CRU numbers. So, of course, the pricing of the first quarter was based up
componenttext: The other factor that plays into it would be the contract pricing. We have about 35% to 40% of our Sheet business is based upon contract pricing, some of which is based on quarterly CRU numbers. So, of course, the pricing of the first quarter was based upon the fourth quarter of last year, CRU average pricing. In the second quarter, we benefited from the higher CRU pricing in the first quarter.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Got you. So wouldn't that also help into the third quarter, or how do we think about that?
componenttext: Got you. So wouldn't that also help into the third quarter, or how do we think about that?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: To some level, to some extent, it will.
componenttext: To some level, to some extent, it will.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. The other question I have is, again, in light of the sheet oversupply problems you talk about, have you thought about -- and I think you addressed a little bit containing production. Is there a way that you think about exports, at what price
componenttext: Okay. Great. The other question I have is, again, in light of the sheet oversupply problems you talk about, have you thought about -- and I think you addressed a little bit containing production. Is there a way that you think about exports, at what price are or at what -- how do you think about the export market as a potential way to address the oversupply in the sheet market?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, our way to address any oversupply situation is just to be extremely competitive, and be successful based upon our cost structures and our customer service and quality for our product range we have. As far as exports go, regardless of what's going on
componenttext: Well, our way to address any oversupply situation is just to be extremely competitive, and be successful based upon our cost structures and our customer service and quality for our product range we have. As far as exports go, regardless of what's going on in the domestic market, we are active on the export front, always looking for opportunities. And particularly -- and that even without the additional capacity coming on stream, the industry is not running at full capacity. So it's been a long-term focus of ours to grow our exports. We were working on that and exporting quite significantly in '06, '07, '08, and it continues through this downturn as well. So it's not something that I would say is -- we at all focused because of domestic overcapacity. That we deal with by being as competitive as possible to get as much business as we can bring into our operations.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's understood, okay. But do you have the percentage that you've given us in the past in terms of expert tons?
componenttext: That's understood, okay. But do you have the percentage that you've given us in the past in terms of expert tons?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me ask John.
componenttext: Let me ask John.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: So the second quarter was basically unchanged from the first quarter, we’re always in that neighborhood of 9% to 11%. And that's what it was for the second quarter. It was about 9.5%.
componenttext: So the second quarter was basically unchanged from the first quarter, we’re always in that neighborhood of 9% to 11%. And that's what it was for the second quarter. It was about 9.5%.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Evan Kurtz with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Evan Kurtz with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just one question on the SBQ market. It seems to be very tight, I hear some products are out close to the end of 2012 at this point. And I just wanted to kind of get your opinion on what the demand for this market looks like longer-term. I know there's be
componenttext: Just one question on the SBQ market. It seems to be very tight, I hear some products are out close to the end of 2012 at this point. And I just wanted to kind of get your opinion on what the demand for this market looks like longer-term. I know there's been about 1 million tons kind of knocked off-line by Republic. But at the same time, we’ve seeing a lot of restarts, Memphis and some others kind of offsetting that. And certainly, the economy is not running at full speed here, we’re nowhere near 16 million auto builds. So what's really driving the tightness in that market, and has something structural changed on the demand side?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's principally -- automotive has uptick compared to a year ago without a doubt. It's way below its peak, no doubt there either. But I think we're -- the agricultural sectors, the heavy equipment sectors, the customers like Caterpillar and John Deere and
componenttext: It's principally -- automotive has uptick compared to a year ago without a doubt. It's way below its peak, no doubt there either. But I think we're -- the agricultural sectors, the heavy equipment sectors, the customers like Caterpillar and John Deere and so on, that's where a lot of demand is coming from, and will continue to come from.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Arun Viswanathan with Susquehanna.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Arun Viswanathan with Susquehanna.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I had a question about the capacity additions. You referenced that and definitely, I can recognize a threat. Has that been localized to any specific regions or are you seeing the supply kind of hit several different areas?
componenttext: I had a question about the capacity additions. You referenced that and definitely, I can recognize a threat. Has that been localized to any specific regions or are you seeing the supply kind of hit several different areas?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Any suggestion that it is localized is pure poppycock. We have 1.3 million tons of flat-rolled steel coming into the United States from every direction in the world. So you put that in perspective with whether or not the excess capacity is coming from Bal
componenttext: Any suggestion that it is localized is pure poppycock. We have 1.3 million tons of flat-rolled steel coming into the United States from every direction in the world. So you put that in perspective with whether or not the excess capacity is coming from Baltimore or Pennsylvania or Alabama or Mississippi. It's immaterial. Everybody feels the pressure of the additional capacity coming to the U.S. market, whether it be domestic or import. I think it's felt by everybody. There's nobody immune from it by any stretch of the imagination. And if you take a look at the history, you'll find that to be extremely true.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, yes. And similarly, can you characterize it as impacting any one market, product-wise, versus others?
componenttext: Okay, yes. And similarly, can you characterize it as impacting any one market, product-wise, versus others?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. It's one of those things, where if it was to be a localized increased capacity, into some special sector of the market, then the folks that played in that market would soon move their production capability into the lower end of the market and vice ver
componenttext: No. It's one of those things, where if it was to be a localized increased capacity, into some special sector of the market, then the folks that played in that market would soon move their production capability into the lower end of the market and vice versa. It doesn't take very long for it to shakeout because it's impacting all the players.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just lastly, on this issue, I'm just curious, I mean, I know that you guys have one of the lowest cost structures in the industry. So you've noted that prices appear to have a bottomed. What's the capacity for these folks to continue to be compe
componenttext: Okay. And just lastly, on this issue, I'm just curious, I mean, I know that you guys have one of the lowest cost structures in the industry. So you've noted that prices appear to have a bottomed. What's the capacity for these folks to continue to be competitive on the pricing front? And are you kind of concerned that prices could go lower as they try to steal more share?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, first off, as John mentioned in his remarks, our view of pricing at this point in time is that it's at or near the bottom on flat-roll, but that's just our best-guess. There's been a significant drop-off in pricing, about $190 a ton. And in the publ
componenttext: Well, first off, as John mentioned in his remarks, our view of pricing at this point in time is that it's at or near the bottom on flat-roll, but that's just our best-guess. There's been a significant drop-off in pricing, about $190 a ton. And in the published market place, this is not our numbers, it's the published marketplace numbers. And I guess you should ask folks that have to decide on whether they want to continue to be -- whether they want to make any money doing what they're doing or continue to lose money.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: When you look at it, Dan, the input costs to the steelmaking prices, they've held pretty steady. So that will certainly have an impact on their -- on everyone's profitability and margins.
componenttext: When you look at it, Dan, the input costs to the steelmaking prices, they've held pretty steady. So that will certainly have an impact on their -- on everyone's profitability and margins.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: And so on that point, do you expect any relief on scrap or alloys or anything else in coming quarters or...
componenttext: And so on that point, do you expect any relief on scrap or alloys or anything else in coming quarters or...

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our view has always been that we're lousy forecasters of what's going to happen on the raw materials side. But I would say that under current conditions, we don't see any severe upward pressure, maybe some slight downward pressure, but pretty much flat as
componenttext: Our view has always been that we're lousy forecasters of what's going to happen on the raw materials side. But I would say that under current conditions, we don't see any severe upward pressure, maybe some slight downward pressure, but pretty much flat as we go forward. But like I said earlier, if there are any decreases in raw material costs, that will pass through to the third quarter for, virtually, everybody unless they‘ve overstocked their inventories. And likewise, on pricing, any pricing improvements will go through pretty quickly into the third quarter because of the overall lead times in the industry.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Mark Parr with KeyBanc.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Mark Parr with KeyBanc.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was wondering on the construction market commentary, that's somewhat new for you in terms of talking about things, showing some modest growth. Could you give us some color on where you're seeing the growth coming from? Is there anything specific that we
componenttext: I was wondering on the construction market commentary, that's somewhat new for you in terms of talking about things, showing some modest growth. Could you give us some color on where you're seeing the growth coming from? Is there anything specific that we could look to?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think for the most part, non-residential construction, multi-dwelling apartments, there is some slight improvements in activity there. But nothing that we would quantify as being strong by any stretch of the imagination. But you've seen some numbers rec
componenttext: I think for the most part, non-residential construction, multi-dwelling apartments, there is some slight improvements in activity there. But nothing that we would quantify as being strong by any stretch of the imagination. But you've seen some numbers recently, where multi-family dwellings are up 30% compared to previous time periods. We're seeing some infrastructure activity but nothing of any major type that is needed in this country. It's just a general fact that we've been at the bottom, and there was no where else to go but up, and so we started to see some just gradual increases in activity.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we've been very clear that they've been modest and small increases. We've been very clear about that.
componenttext: I think we've been very clear that they've been modest and small increases. We've been very clear about that.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, but it's just nice to see what appears to be at least somewhat of an inflection, yes, however tepid and modest. But at least it's a beginning, so that's encouraging. Another thing, I was curious about, there’s -- earlier this week, one of your
componenttext: Yes, no, but it's just nice to see what appears to be at least somewhat of an inflection, yes, however tepid and modest. But at least it's a beginning, so that's encouraging. Another thing, I was curious about, there’s -- earlier this week, one of your competitors had indicated some thoughts about potential for sheet pricing to show inflection and moving up. If you look at the futures markets, they've moved actually off of bottom here just in the last week. And the futures prices for moving into the first half are a lot stronger than they are in the fourth quarter, also the differential between U.S. pricing and Chinese, the Shanghai export price is at what I would characterize as an unsustainably low level, indicating some upward momentum opportunity for U.S. sheet pricing. Is there any color that you can give in terms of your own opinion on when you think some pricing inflection might unfold here?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we've already made the comments that we feel like the pricing is at or near bottom, so the odds of it going up are greater than going down. But you can't get away from the fact that whether it’s imports from overseas, bringing on additional capa
componenttext: I think we've already made the comments that we feel like the pricing is at or near bottom, so the odds of it going up are greater than going down. But you can't get away from the fact that whether it’s imports from overseas, bringing on additional capacity and excessive demand or it’s new capacity coming on stream domestically, that's an issue that has to be dealt with. It can't be ignored. It's real, and it will have an impact on exactly what strengthening takes place in the quarter, and it's way too early to tell how are people going to behave in the marketplace. It's -- everybody's out there, trying to do for their companies what they can do to be more profitable and bring in more volume. So I continue to believe, we continue to believe, it’s going to be a very competitive marketplace.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I could ask just one last question. Certainly -- on the second quarter, there were a lot of unusual issues, which you talked about. Is there any help you can give us to try to at least attempt to quantify how much of a cost impact there was?
componenttext: Okay. If I could ask just one last question. Certainly -- on the second quarter, there were a lot of unusual issues, which you talked about. Is there any help you can give us to try to at least attempt to quantify how much of a cost impact there was?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: The impact is in lost volume. And so, I mean, you imagine keeping all your teammates employed and actually helping out in the communities where you’re paying them for their efforts to salvage homes, save people who are buried under stuff and trees and c
componenttext: The impact is in lost volume. And so, I mean, you imagine keeping all your teammates employed and actually helping out in the communities where you’re paying them for their efforts to salvage homes, save people who are buried under stuff and trees and collapsed houses, you name it, and you're not producing any steel, there’s a major cost impact. We didn't lay our folks off. We kept them busy, and there was a significant impact, maybe not on existing orders on the books as we moved them very well to our other operations to fill those orders. But when you're sitting there, you're telling your customers, well, the PBA's telling us 3 to 5 weeks, you're probably not going to get kind of order entry that you're going to need to build your order book at that location going forward. To put a cost number on it is difficult. We basically lost a little over a month’s production at that facility, which does 50,000 tons a week or more.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we did lose some out of Tuscaloosa also.
componenttext: And we did lose some out of Tuscaloosa also.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. We lost production in Tuscaloosa.
componenttext: Yes. We lost production in Tuscaloosa.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: So I can try to work on what that might work out to be.
componenttext: So I can try to work on what that might work out to be.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: And the only thing that I would put in front of you is rather than trying to get to fancy about figuring all that out, just focus on the fact that profitability in the quarter was extremely strong in spite of that.
componenttext: And the only thing that I would put in front of you is rather than trying to get to fancy about figuring all that out, just focus on the fact that profitability in the quarter was extremely strong in spite of that.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Aldo Mazzaferro with Burke & Quick.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Aldo Mazzaferro with Burke & Quick.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was pretty impressed with your metal spreads in the sheet area and in the structural area. But in the sheet area, would it be fair for me to think that some of the pricing improvement was due to the mix, and the mix was really due to the outage at Decat
componenttext: I was pretty impressed with your metal spreads in the sheet area and in the structural area. But in the sheet area, would it be fair for me to think that some of the pricing improvement was due to the mix, and the mix was really due to the outage at Decatur where you kind of saved the high-value products and gave up the hot-rolled?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, we didn't give up anything. We just made sure we didn't fall down on our customers needs when they were -- if they had the commitment from us to provide them the steal out of Decatur, fill those orders. Certainly, mix always has a role to play, I thin
componenttext: No, we didn't give up anything. We just made sure we didn't fall down on our customers needs when they were -- if they had the commitment from us to provide them the steal out of Decatur, fill those orders. Certainly, mix always has a role to play, I think John talked about a little bit already. But I wouldn't say it in the way that you just put it, Aldo. John?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, Dan, you're spot on. Mix, we had a slightly different mix for the quarter, but it would not have impacted the margin significantly.
componenttext: No, Dan, you're spot on. Mix, we had a slightly different mix for the quarter, but it would not have impacted the margin significantly.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guarantee if anybody told me they turned away a hot-roll orders, they’d have heard from me.
componenttext: I guarantee if anybody told me they turned away a hot-roll orders, they’d have heard from me.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: So in terms of your third quarter comment that you might have lowered numbers, is it -- would it be metal spread considerations that you're looking at when you think that way?
componenttext: So in terms of your third quarter comment that you might have lowered numbers, is it -- would it be metal spread considerations that you're looking at when you think that way?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. Absolutely, I mean, Aldo, pricing is going from the peak of 890 to -- soon to be 700. You haven't seen scrap come down $200 a ton, have you, or iron ore or coke and coal or anything else?
componenttext: Absolutely. Absolutely, I mean, Aldo, pricing is going from the peak of 890 to -- soon to be 700. You haven't seen scrap come down $200 a ton, have you, or iron ore or coke and coal or anything else?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Are you seeing any increased electricity cost on a kilowatt basis or per ton basis due to the heat?
componenttext: Are you seeing any increased electricity cost on a kilowatt basis or per ton basis due to the heat?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Not really. I think we spoke to our energy numbers in the press release. They're about $3 a ton higher, but nothing out of the ordinary.
componenttext: Not really. I think we spoke to our energy numbers in the press release. They're about $3 a ton higher, but nothing out of the ordinary.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: All right. Then just finally, how's the European JV doing with the Italian/Greece contango there in the credit markets? And generally, are you seeing any improvement, or how’s the export potential from the U.S.?
componenttext: All right. Then just finally, how's the European JV doing with the Italian/Greece contango there in the credit markets? And generally, are you seeing any improvement, or how’s the export potential from the U.S.?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, first off, question related to our joint venture, which is known as Duferdofin with our partners at Duferco. Under the circumstances, and it significantly impacted construction markets in Europe and Southern Europe, they're doing very well. And ther
componenttext: Well, first off, question related to our joint venture, which is known as Duferdofin with our partners at Duferco. Under the circumstances, and it significantly impacted construction markets in Europe and Southern Europe, they're doing very well. And there are plenty of opportunities for us to improve their cost structure even further even in these lousy conditions, which our teams are working on as we speak to improve their situation even more. But they're more than holding their own, and not a major drain on Nucor at all.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And any export, anything on the export front that you can talk about?
componenttext: Great. And any export, anything on the export front that you can talk about?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think pricing has got more competitive. So I think we'll see some more opportunities. But it's nothing out of the ordinary. I don't think we expect to see much improvement in exports, percentage-wise, in third quarter than second quarter.
componenttext: I think pricing has got more competitive. So I think we'll see some more opportunities. But it's nothing out of the ordinary. I don't think we expect to see much improvement in exports, percentage-wise, in third quarter than second quarter.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: It’ll be about the same.
componenttext: It’ll be about the same.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Richard Garchitorena with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Richard Garchitorena with Credit Suisse.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question, are there any maintenance outages expected in Q3 or...
componenttext: Just a quick question, are there any maintenance outages expected in Q3 or...

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: We have a few that are scheduled, nothing major, a couple of days here and there during the quarter, but we have no major outages. We do have our -- we currently have our Trinidad DRI facility down for a major outage, but that will be returning at the end
componenttext: We have a few that are scheduled, nothing major, a couple of days here and there during the quarter, but we have no major outages. We do have our -- we currently have our Trinidad DRI facility down for a major outage, but that will be returning at the end of this month. The reason it has been down is to expand our capacity from about 1.8 million tons up to 2 million tons in Trinidad.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And on SG&A, it looks like went up slightly as a percentage of sales, to 2.9. Is that related to just the increase to profitability, or is there anything else specific than that?
componenttext: Great. And on SG&A, it looks like went up slightly as a percentage of sales, to 2.9. Is that related to just the increase to profitability, or is there anything else specific than that?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is profit sharing increases. Obviously, the more profitable we get, so that has to be put aside, so that's principally it.
componenttext: Yes, it is profit sharing increases. Obviously, the more profitable we get, so that has to be put aside, so that's principally it.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011

componenttext: Our next question comes from Sal Tharani with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011

componenttext: Dan, it was very good to see that the equity contribution from consolidated affiliates went to positive income for a long time. I believe it's – were you profitable at Duferdofin or was it all NuMit which actually more than offset the Italian joint venture losses?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011

componenttext: Actually, there's several other items in that category. And obviously, we don't break them out. So nice try, Sal. We won't be breaking them out any further, but I'll gave it to you overall. It’s nice to see that net-net-net of the 4 or 5 things that were in that category turning more positive.

componenttextpreview: Okay. Do -- should we actually expect that? I mean, is that something that's changed over there?
componenttext: Okay. Do -- should we actually expect that? I mean, is that something that's changed over there?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011

componenttext: I think they've done a significantly better job this year than last year. While we can't give you the absolute numbers, I think the level of improvement has been -- Joe, you got any percentages in terms of...

componenttextpreview: The level of improvement would be -- I don't have percentages exactly, but it would be a factor of more than doubling their performance.
componenttext: The level of improvement would be -- I don't have percentages exactly, but it would be a factor of more than doubling their performance.

componenttext: Thank you. Again, I would just like to thank everybody who is interested in Nucor's and our shareholders, our teammates. And while third quarter is yet to be accomplished, you can be assured that Nucor will be there at the top of the heap, whatever that level is, and that we'll be competitive. The sheet market will now become one of the more challenging ones because of the capacity situations. It's not the first time that we've met challenges like that before and we will again. headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Nucor Corporation's Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] Certain statements made during this conference call will be forward-lookin
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Nucor Corporation's Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] Certain statements made during this conference call will be forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Although Nucor believes they are based on reasonable assumptions, there can be no assurance that future events will not affect their accuracy. For more information about the risks and uncertainties relating to these forward-looking statements may be found in the Nucor's latest 10-K and subsequently filed 10-Q, which are available on the SEC's and Nucor's website. The forward-looking statements made in this conference call speak only as of this date, and Nucor does not assume any obligation to update them either as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. Now for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Dan DiMicco, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Nucor Corporation. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stacy. Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our conference call, and as always, we appreciate your interest in Nucor. With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor's senior management  team: our President and Chief Operating O
componenttext: Thank you, Stacy. Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our conference call, and as always, we appreciate your interest in Nucor. With me for today's call are the other members of Nucor's senior management  team: our President and Chief Operating Officer, John Ferriola; our Chief  Financial Officer, Jim Frias; and our Executive Vice Presidents: Jim  Darsey; Keith Grass; Ladd Hall; and Joe Stratman. First, and most importantly, I want to thank everyone on our team at Nucor and our Harris Steel and David J. Joseph Co.'s us for her excellent work in economic environment that remains extremely challenging. We are working safely, and as always, you are working together as a team to take care of our customers and our shareholders. And your work goes far beyond the significant demands of getting the job done each quarter. Your successfully implementing numerous growth initiatives that are building a stronger Nucor. Our stronger Nucor and I'm describing 1 position for new higher highs and cyclical earnings power of sustainable economic recovery arrives. Thank you, all. I'll now ask our CFO, Jim Frias, to discuss our second quarter results, following Jim's comments, President and COO, John Ferriola will report on our operations and implementation of our growth initiatives. As you listen to the reports, I believe there are 2 very important points you need to consider. First, our third quarter and first 9 months results benefited greatly from Nucor's position as North Americas most diversified steelmaker. Product diversification is a critical building block in Nucor's business model. And our business model, with its flexibility, diversification and sustainability, is what drives Nucor's industry-leading through the cycle return on capital performance. Second, Nucor's growing stronger during its downturn. Throughout Nucor, our teams are growing long-term earnings power, in upstream Raw Materials and steelmaking and in downstream steel products. How can we do that? How can we expand while others are focused on survival? The answer is simple. Our business model in our strong balance sheet allows us to focus on a long-term and grow stronger during the downturns. At this time, I'd like to turn it over to Mr. Frias, our CFO for his comments. Jim?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan, and good afternoon. Third quarter 2011 earnings of $0.57 per diluted share exceeded our guidance range of $0.45 to $0.55 per diluted share. Our results increased more than eightfold over third quarter of 2010 earnings, but decreased 39% from
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan, and good afternoon. Third quarter 2011 earnings of $0.57 per diluted share exceeded our guidance range of $0.45 to $0.55 per diluted share. Our results increased more than eightfold over third quarter of 2010 earnings, but decreased 39% from second quarter 2011 earnings of $0.94 per diluted share. The third quarter 2011 effective tax rate, measured as a percentage of earnings before income taxes and noncontrolling interests, was 29.6%. However, after adjusting our profits belonging to our noncontrolling interests business partners, the effective tax rate was 31.7%. Excluding state income tax credits recorded during the quarter, the effective tax rate would have been about 34%. However, the positive impact on earnings from the state tax credits was essentially offset by other nonrecurring items recorded in the third quarter. As we expected, third quarter results and profits were below our second quarter results. The quarter-over-quarter decline was primarily due to lower prices and metal margins for Sheet Mill Group next. The sheet market has been severely impacted by new domestic supply and increased imports. Importantly, Nucor continues to benefit from a diversified product mix. In fact, our bar mills and deck fabricating plans delivered solid improvement over their second quarter profitability. Earnings in our plate mills were essentially flat with the second quarter. However, the trend for the plate mills was down through quarter due to the impact of higher imports. Our be downstream cold-finished bar businesses experienced the small decline in quarter-over-quarter results but continued to contributes solid profits. 
Earnings per diluted share of $2.02 for the 9 months of 2011 represents a dramatic improvement from the year ago periods earnings per share of $0.46. That's an increase of 340%. Cash generated from operations is also up strongly, nearly triple the prior year period. And Nucor's annualized return on equity through this year's first 9 months is a respectable 12%. The Nucor team is achieving this performance in an economy which nonresidential construction, square footage for 2011 is forecast to be more than 60% below the peak level reached in 2007. Our returns are also achieved at the lowest financial leverage in the industry. While construction remains our largest end-user market, Nucor's unrivaled combination of product diversification and operational flexibility allows us to grow our participation in other more robust markets. These include end-use market such as automotive, heavy equipment, energy and general manufacturing. Throughout Nucor, our team mates are enjoying tremendous success developing new products, as well as other continual improvement initiatives that both reduce costs and improve quality across our entire product portfolio. It goes back to Dan's point, our to the team uses economic downturns as opportunities to grow stronger. Emerging from downturn stronger than we enter them is how we build long-term value for our shareholders. We get stronger because our financial strength allows us to invest in an attractive growth opportunities throughout economic cycle. 
At the close of the third quarter, cash and short-term investments and restricted cash totaled over $3 billion. The restricted cash is available to fund a significant portion of the plant that we are building Louisiana. Further to Nucor's strong liquidity, our $1.3 billion unsecured revolving credit facility is undrawn and does not mature until November 2012. We have no commercial paper outstanding. Long-term debt totaled $4.3 billion at the end of the second quarter, for a gross debt-to-capital ratio of 36%. Moody's has reported that our debt-to-capital ratio will be viewed on a net debt basis for any cash and short-term investments balance over $1.2 billion. Using that methodology, our net debt-to-capital ratio is 29%. That calculation excludes the restricted cash. 
Looking ahead, our debt-to-capital ratio is expected to decline as the result of upcoming long-term debt maturities of $650 million in 2012 and $250 million in 2013. We expect to fund those maturities by drawing on our healthy liquidity position and continued strong operating cash flows. Standard & Poor's in its October 4 report entitled, North American Metals and Mining Companies Strongest to Weakest, again ranked Nucor number 1 for credit rating and credit outlook among a universe of 64 companies. Nucor was also the only metals and mining company in the group that S&P awarded a strong business risk profile due to our competitive position and profit performance relative to our peers. 
In 2011, we are continuing to invest in projects that will grow our long-term earnings power and provide attractive returns to our shareholders. We project 2011 capital spending of approximately $475 million. That is down from our prior estimate mainly due to the timing of expenditures for equipment at Nucor Steel Louisiana. John Ferriola will give you an update on some of our more significant growth projects in his remarks. 
Our outlook for the fourth quarter is tempered by the expectation of further margin compression in the sheet market due to the supply side pressures from new domestic supply and imports. We also anticipate some margin compression in the plate market due to increased imports. This margin compression for sheet and plate products may be cushioned somewhat by trend of lower scrap prices we see beginning to emerge in October. Overall, we expect Nucor's fourth quarter earnings to decline from the third quarter level. Demand in end-use market such as automotive, energy, heavy equipment and general manufacturing remains firm, but have shown very little improvement compared to the first half of 2011. Nucor's combined construction businesses, that's Long Products steel mills and downstream operations, are expected to continue to operate profitably. This profitability has been achieved even though we have seen no real improvement in nonresidential construction markets in 2011. 
Nucor will again follow our practice of providing quantitative guidance around the middle of the final month of the quarter. We are excited by the opportunities ahead to deliver higher highs in earnings when the inevitable cyclical recovery finally arrives. Again, the key to our performance, and most importantly, our ability to reward our shareholders is the flexibility, diversification and sustainability found in our business model. Thank you for your interest in Nucor. Dan?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. Good afternoon. Let me begin by thanking all of our raw materials, steelmaking and steel product teammates for your outstanding commitment to working safely and to taking care of Nucor's customers. When I visit our operations, I am always imp
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. Good afternoon. Let me begin by thanking all of our raw materials, steelmaking and steel product teammates for your outstanding commitment to working safely and to taking care of Nucor's customers. When I visit our operations, I am always impressed, and quite frankly, inspired by the work of the more than 20,000 men and women of Nucor are doing everyday to profitably grow our business for the long-term. Thank you, and please, keep it going. 
Dan and Jim both mentioned the importance of Nucor's product diversification. This is highlighted by quarter-over-quarter changes in our average selling prices. Our third quarter sheet mill average selling price declined $94 per ton from the second quarter. By contrast, our composite steel mill average sales price decreased by just $44 per ton over this period. Traumatic price erosion in the sheet market was cushioned by greater stability and the selling prices of our other steel mill products. Our bar, Beam and Plate mills combined, provided 61% of Nucor's total steel mill shipments in the third quarter. And our downstream steel products businesses realized a $20 per ton increase and they are composite third quarter average selling price from the second quarter level. 
I want to reiterate an extremely important point that investors need to understand about Nucor. Our business model, with its flexibility, diversification and sustainability, is what drives Nucor's industry-leading through the cycle return on capital performance, and our business model is getting stronger during this downturn. I will provide brief updates on some of our initiatives to grow long-term earnings power. Our team at the Memphis SBQ mill set new shipment and profitability records in the third quarter, and Memphis continues to gain product qualifications and production volumes for OEMs in the construction equipment, automotive, heavy truck, farm equipment and energy markets. Our team at Nucor Steel Nebraska successfully started up a downstream processing line that provides new growth opportunities and even higher-quality SBQ products than they currently offer. Our Sheet Mill Group continues to be successful at introducing new Value Added Products for a variety of end-use markets such as heavy equipment, energy, automotive, railcar and metal framing. 
Additional value-added steelmaking capabilities are on the horizon for Nucor. Projects underway include a normalizing line in vacuum tank degas are at our North Carolina plate mill, an equipment upgraded will allow us to reduce lighter gauge and wider product at our South Carolina sheet mill and a vacuum tank to Gasser at our Arkansas sheet mill. 
Our team achieved record scrap export container shipments during the third quarter. And DJJ continues to grow its businesses in other areas as well. Nonferrous metal facilities are being added in Tampa, Florida and Louisville, Kentucky. 
Nucor's downstream businesses are gaining market share as the result of product innovations and commercial excellence in taking care of our customers. Examples include the Vulcraft Verco groups, 3-D Building Information Modeling and the proprietary Ecospan composite floor system. Nucor's Building Systems group is growing its distribution network both in terms of quantity and quality. And our Harris Steel Rebar Fabrication business continues to expand both its footprint and its product capabilities. Our Nucor Steel Louisiana team is on schedule with construction of our 2.5 million tons per year Direct Reduced Iron or DRI facility. Start up is expected in mid-2013. Combines with our new iron DRI facility in Trinidad, the first module at Louisiana will bring us to about 2/3 of our goal to control 6 million to 7 million tons of annual capacity and high-quality scrap substitutes. Rate of control of high quality iron used assumed that our steel mills will be a very high return investment for Nucor. The projects I just discussed and many others throughout our company demonstrate how downturns create opportunities for Nucor. Opportunities for our long-term, sustainable, profitable growth. That's the reason why we are very optimistic about our teams ability to deliver higher highs in earnings on an inevitable cyclical recovery arrives. Thank you for your interest in our company. Dan?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. The U.S. economy continues to struggle to emerge from the Great Recession. It has been able to move to a path of and sustainable growth. This is not surprising. Our nation has failed to implement real solutions to eliminate the nonsustain
componenttext:
Thank you, John. The U.S. economy continues to struggle to emerge from the Great Recession. It has been able to move to a path of and sustainable growth. This is not surprising. Our nation has failed to implement real solutions to eliminate the nonsustainable structural imbalances that drag economy deeper in deeper into a hole of low or no growth. Our team been adamant, persistent over the past 3 years with our views on the way forward to a stronger and more sustainable American economy. And we require real solutions that eliminate the structural imbalances, and at the same time, create what our economy needs most, jobs, jobs and more jobs. This can be accomplished with multi pronged plan for the U.S., to achieve new energy independence, enforce rules basic trade, to build our crumbling infrastructure, reform and simplify the tax code and reduce the burden of excessive regulation on our economy. 
I would like to comment on 2 developments regarding enforcement of our nation's trade laws. First, the United States Senate last week past a bipartisan currency exchange rate oversight reformat of 2011. This legislation is exactly the kind of strong and bipartisan action our government must take to hold China accountable for its protectionist trade policies. China's failure to engage in rules based trade, a commitment it agreed to when it became a member of the World Trade Organization and achieved favored nation trading status in the United States, has destroyed many years of good paying American jobs. It is now time for the United States House of Representatives to pass this bill. It will be a big step forward in restoring free and fair competition in our global trading system. The idea that somehow this action will create a trade war is both ludicrous and ignorant, with an emphasis on ignorant. Why? Because we have been in a trade war waged by the Chinese government for 16 years, except that our government has yet to join the fight and we're losing miserably. The evidence, you say, where is it? try a greater than a $2.2 trillion trade deficit with China over the last 11 years, greater than $2.2 trillion in manufactured goods over the last 11 years. American manufacturing, American jobs and the American middle class have borne the brunt of this trade war. It is time to say, enough is enough, and act legally to hold them accountable. This is one area that the current administration has done a better job of than the previous Clinton and Bush administrations, but is still way short of what is needed. 
The second development is the U.S. International Trade Commission's Sunset review of anti-dumping and counter duly orders on custom lend plate from India, Indonesia, Italy, Japan and Korea. Maintaining these orders is critical to the health of the U.S. plate market. These orders will help to ensure that illegally traded plate imports from these countries do not return to the U.S. market as they once did. Free and fair trade in the U.S. plate market is an absolute requirement for Nucor to continue investing capital and adding jobs in this business. 
These are extremely challenging and uncertain times for the overall economy and the steel industry. However, one thing is for certain, and it is very much under our control. The Nucor team will meet any and all challenges head on and turn them into opportunities. We are primed and ready to continue growing stronger. That is exactly what our team is been doing for more than 4 decades. At this time, we'd be happy to take your questions.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011

componenttextpreview: Just a quick one about what about your view on supple in the market. Obviously, we have short leadtimes here on flatrolleds. You talked about some of the new competitors making waves in the market. When I think about flatrolled pricing, right now, the pri
componenttext: Just a quick one about what about your view on supple in the market. Obviously, we have short leadtimes here on flatrolleds. You talked about some of the new competitors making waves in the market. When I think about flatrolled pricing, right now, the pricing structure seems to be more driven by cost push as scrap and iron go up and down. When you think about kind of what level we need to get back to have more pricing power in flatrolled, what kind of lead times do you think that correlates to?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it wouldn't be appropriate to be getting into conversations about pricing power. But I will make 2 comments. One, in today's environment, the raw material push is not what's driving pricing in the marketplace. Was driving pricing in the marketplace
componenttext: Well, it wouldn't be appropriate to be getting into conversations about pricing power. But I will make 2 comments. One, in today's environment, the raw material push is not what's driving pricing in the marketplace. Was driving pricing in the marketplace is a massive overcapacity that's being created by additional new capacity coming on stream, increased imports from overseas, particularly in flatrolled, and a demand in their economy that is not growing to any measurable rate at this point in time. That complete supply-demand situation is what is dictating pricing in the marketplace today more than raw materials because raw materials have been fairly steady over the past little while so that would be the only comment I would make on that.

componenttext: So I guess, similar types of concerns on my end to Kuni's, I was just wondering, are you seeing any signs yet of matching production with demand out there, it seems like the industry is still oversupplying the market. Would you guys take a leadership position potentially to bring down production if needed to reduce supply?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Boy, what a loaded question. Listen, I'm not going to comment on what should or shouldn't be done out there. All I can do is tell you how Nucor handles its operating rates and production rates, and it's based upon the level of orders we get in. We're very
componenttext: Boy, what a loaded question. Listen, I'm not going to comment on what should or shouldn't be done out there. All I can do is tell you how Nucor handles its operating rates and production rates, and it's based upon the level of orders we get in. We're very competitive in the marketplace. We will continue to be very competitive and meet all competitive challenges out there. How much we've run or don't run is completely predicated upon the order entry level we get as has been mentioned, the lead times are very short, particularly in the flatrolled side I mean the order entry that we're reacting to is that we see on a week-to-week, month-to-month basis and more towards the week-to-week right now. Then we have the luxury at our facilities, electric furnace shops of literally being able to turn the light switch on at a moment's notice. With orders pick up we increase production instantaneously. If the orders go down, we decrease the production instantaneously. And our customers dictate and our success in attracting our customers orders dictates how much we run.

componenttext: Okay. That was kind of what that was wondering about. What's driving behind that commentary?

componenttextpreview: Well, there's a number of things that influence our mix and I'll let John talk to that. There was 1 comment that was just made to me by Jim Frias, and that is, we have the impact in the second quarter of the tornadoes that occurred in Alabama on 2 of our
componenttext: Well, there's a number of things that influence our mix and I'll let John talk to that. There was 1 comment that was just made to me by Jim Frias, and that is, we have the impact in the second quarter of the tornadoes that occurred in Alabama on 2 of our mills, our plate mill, it's a really a combo plate mill, sheet mill in Oskaloosa and our sheet million in Decatur. So that did have some influence on mix. John, do you have any comments on that?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: The only comment I'd make is in terms of mix, I assume you mean that in all of our products, we're moving higher into the value-added products, and that's a conscious decision we've made on all of our product lines in plate in bars and SBQ in flatrolled.
componenttext: The only comment I'd make is in terms of mix, I assume you mean that in all of our products, we're moving higher into the value-added products, and that's a conscious decision we've made on all of our product lines in plate in bars and SBQ in flatrolled. And obviously, that's a reaction to many things, to market needs. And also the import situation, imports basically are driven by commodity items and by continuing to move further up the value chain, we gain a little bit of protection from that, and we find new ways and new products to grow our market share.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011

componenttext: Yes, I guess just to clarify then, so if your average prices were up sequentially from the first quarter to second quarter, somewhat commensurate with flat rolled benchmarks. Was it mix improvement? And then does that mean that fourth quarter, you're going to some of the price declines that actually were going to impact third quarter?

componenttext: No to the last point that you just made. And our product diversification is just really all 3 of us have discussed in our prepared remarks. headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Without having those exact words in front of us, I really don't see where there should be much of a difference between the 2. Our guidance is completely qualitative at this point in time. We are indicating that there will be a reduction in our profit
componenttext: Yes. Without having those exact words in front of us, I really don't see where there should be much of a difference between the 2. Our guidance is completely qualitative at this point in time. We are indicating that there will be a reduction in our profitability because of this particular situation in the sheet market. And but there is something that we are seeing right now that we didn't see coming into the third quarter, and that is, there seems to be some moderation in scrap pricing that may continue throughout the quarter, which will help us on margin retention. But how that all shakes out? There's a lag time between what we purchase on scrap and the pricing we pay. And then what the usage numbers are and the cost for the scrap at shop, usually, there's a 2 to 4 week lag time between purchases and usage, depending upon the inventory levels at the mills themselves. So that's a little bit of an unknown. It's floating out there, but that should be an unknown that breaks in the positive direction rather than in a negative one. So maybe that's the reason for it, Tony.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011

componenttext: Okay. Understood. And then just another question, too, is this the kind of market, obviously, a slow growth environment in which you guys believe strongly that you can excel because of what you're doing and how you're differentiating the company versus others in the industry?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, absolutely. And that shows up in the results. It's shown up in the results for third quarter. It's shown up in the results for our year-to-date numbers over last year. And it shows up throughout history of the company, including the last 11 ye
componenttext: Absolutely, absolutely. And that shows up in the results. It's shown up in the results for third quarter. It's shown up in the results for our year-to-date numbers over last year. And it shows up throughout history of the company, including the last 11 years of this executive team has been lucky enough to lead this company. So yes, we absolutely believe it. And it's our strong financial position and our strong business model that gives us the confidence to be able to say that. And our teammates who are out there every day, finding new ways, better rates, safer ways to do things.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Brian Yu with Citi.
componenttext: We'll go next to Brian Yu with Citi.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Then, you've got more of a strategy I guess a type of question. With DRI, you're obviously taking control of your carbon costs. There has been some announcements on the Ironside. I want to see what your thoughts are on perhaps taking control of your own d
componenttext: Then, you've got more of a strategy I guess a type of question. With DRI, you're obviously taking control of your carbon costs. There has been some announcements on the Ironside. I want to see what your thoughts are on perhaps taking control of your own destiny on this ferrous side, too.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, what we're doing on the direct reduced iron side, it doesn't take us all away to the beginning of the process which would be mining. But it does give us more control over production, distribution channels, how far those distribution channels are str
componenttext: Well, what we're doing on the direct reduced iron side, it doesn't take us all away to the beginning of the process which would be mining. But it does give us more control over production, distribution channels, how far those distribution channels are stretched out, which had a really negative impact on us in the '08, '09 downturn with the pig iron. And with the natural gas situation here in the United States being extremely competitive, it gives us a cost advantage in many respects as well even without the control over the iron ore. And I think that's what you're alluding to getting us into the mining business. That's certainly a possibility that under the right set of opportunities, that we would be willing to partner with somebody that we're involved in getting access to our own iron ore. I wouldn't rule that out, but there's nothing imminent that we are about to announce.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question just on the export I think you're dates in tracking 9% to 10% of shipments, given what's happening in Europe, any updates on that percentage? And then subcomponent, can you differentiate between how much of what you're doing this con
componenttext: Okay. Second question just on the export I think you're dates in tracking 9% to 10% of shipments, given what's happening in Europe, any updates on that percentage? And then subcomponent, can you differentiate between how much of what you're doing this contract versus spot business for exports?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: On exports?
componenttext: On exports?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll take a shot at that, Dan. Our third quarter was a good quarter for us in terms of exporting products. We had been, as you mentioned, we've been running around a 9% or 10%. In the third quarter, we exported about 13.3% of our products. Again, most of
componenttext: I'll take a shot at that, Dan. Our third quarter was a good quarter for us in terms of exporting products. We had been, as you mentioned, we've been running around a 9% or 10%. In the third quarter, we exported about 13.3% of our products. Again, most of it going into the Central and South American region. In terms of contract versus spot on exports, very little of it is contract business on exports, most of it is spot business.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: That is something that as we develop our spot business, we're giving more interest in from the customers in South and Central America in developing a longer-term supplier relationship.
componenttext: That is something that as we develop our spot business, we're giving more interest in from the customers in South and Central America in developing a longer-term supplier relationship.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I might actually build on that and to do that you have to have certain infrastructure in place. In Columbia, we have just put off first a depot, it opened up about a month ago, our first shipment arrived about 3 weeks ago, and we're really excited abo
componenttext: And I might actually build on that and to do that you have to have certain infrastructure in place. In Columbia, we have just put off first a depot, it opened up about a month ago, our first shipment arrived about 3 weeks ago, and we're really excited about that. The Colombian market has been a good market for us. Our sales teams there are doing a good job, and our products are well accepted. And as we continue to move in that direction, we will continue to move up the value chain and that lends itself to more contract business as we go forward. Also, one of the things we're really excited about is the way that we've managed the logistics into that area because of our DRI facility in Trinidad and bringing the DRI back to the states, we've built a circular route, which is really helped us on our freight costs, sending product into South and Central America.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. So you get a little bit of freight advantage on the back?
componenttext: Okay. So you get a little bit of freight advantage on the back?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: A little bit more than a little bit. It actually is quite a significant freight advantage and it's given us an edge in our ability to export our products successfully into those countries.
componenttext: A little bit more than a little bit. It actually is quite a significant freight advantage and it's given us an edge in our ability to export our products successfully into those countries.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: The addition of is the passage of the Colombia Free Trade Agreement, possibly the Panamanian one will also reduce some of the tariffs we've had to pay with our product versus our competition, and make us even more competitive down there. And hopefully, re
componenttext: The addition of is the passage of the Colombia Free Trade Agreement, possibly the Panamanian one will also reduce some of the tariffs we've had to pay with our product versus our competition, and make us even more competitive down there. And hopefully, result in even stronger margins.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: So what type of product are you sending down there?
componenttext: So what type of product are you sending down there?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Everything.
componenttext: Everything.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just to drill down on the freight situation and talking about having the advantage for some of our competition, because we can shift every type of product down there, it allows us to send full boatloads now. We send sheet down there, we sent beam down the
componenttext: Just to drill down on the freight situation and talking about having the advantage for some of our competition, because we can shift every type of product down there, it allows us to send full boatloads now. We send sheet down there, we sent beam down there, we send late down there. We send bar down there, SBQ down there. So we are able to fill up a load without having to depend upon a single product shipment to the region.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Hopefully, we're going to be start to ship down metal building and decks and other things, too.
componenttext: Hopefully, we're going to be start to ship down metal building and decks and other things, too.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011

componenttext: We'll go next to Evan Kurtz with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the construction market. Your language changed a little bit in your press release here, too. Only a minimum improvement from solely improving in the last quarter. I wondered if that was something that was done to -- you kind of show tha
componenttext: Just a question on the construction market. Your language changed a little bit in your press release here, too. Only a minimum improvement from solely improving in the last quarter. I wondered if that was something that was done to -- you kind of show that things may be turning down a little bit. And maybe also if you can comment on where you're seeing your backlogs in the fabrication business as your indicator of construction.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, all that's maintained a fairly steady pace but obviously, a very low rate. And a reason for our change in the wording has to do with the recent information that came out from the AISC, the American and Steel Construction that actually showing that i
componenttext: Well, all that's maintained a fairly steady pace but obviously, a very low rate. And a reason for our change in the wording has to do with the recent information that came out from the AISC, the American and Steel Construction that actually showing that instead of a 5% gain in non-residential construction in 2011 where we we're going to end up with a 1% to 2% fall off negative growth. And that's why our comments were as worded.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right. And backlogs, have they changed much in that?
componenttext: Right. And backlogs, have they changed much in that?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: They've been pretty consistent.
componenttext: They've been pretty consistent.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just 1 more an I know this may be difficult for you to comment on, but just given the recent acting activism over at CMC, would you consider any of their assets that make particular strategic sense under Nucor and should the opportunity ar
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just 1 more an I know this may be difficult for you to comment on, but just given the recent acting activism over at CMC, would you consider any of their assets that make particular strategic sense under Nucor and should the opportunity arise down the road here?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: All I can say is that all along, Nucor has put itself in the position of the opportunistic. And if opportunities come our way, we'll certainly take a look at them. Whether or not we would on that particular asset is something that we probably should avoid
componenttext: All I can say is that all along, Nucor has put itself in the position of the opportunistic. And if opportunities come our way, we'll certainly take a look at them. Whether or not we would on that particular asset is something that we probably should avoid commenting on.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to David MacGregor with Longbow Research.
componenttext: We'll go next to David MacGregor with Longbow Research.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just with respect to the calendar, I mean we're getting pretty close to the end of the year now, what are you hearing anecdotally from your customers with respect to maybe any kind of pickup in orders in the first quarter of next year?
componenttext: Just with respect to the calendar, I mean we're getting pretty close to the end of the year now, what are you hearing anecdotally from your customers with respect to maybe any kind of pickup in orders in the first quarter of next year?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: John?
componenttext: John?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, the end of the year, our customers focus on inventory control and the first part of the year, the most of our products, typically pick up as those inventories that have been completed in the fourth quarter are rebuilt. And we're hearing
componenttext: Well, as you know, the end of the year, our customers focus on inventory control and the first part of the year, the most of our products, typically pick up as those inventories that have been completed in the fourth quarter are rebuilt. And we're hearing pretty much the same this year. We expect the first quarter, from our customers perspective, to be a stronger order entry quarter in most of our products. I think you have an additional to the inventory situation, you have the seasonal things that take place long ago,for example, we'll come back and as you get later into the first quarter, people start thinking about construction as limited as it is again. So the seasonal impact we think will be positive.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Do you think you'll see any -- above and beyond the seasonal pattern, do you think you're going to see any cyclical improvement, first quarter versus first quarter?
componenttext: Do you think you'll see any -- above and beyond the seasonal pattern, do you think you're going to see any cyclical improvement, first quarter versus first quarter?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: No.
componenttext: No.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess second question if I could. Just you talked a lot about investing in the downturn in strategically historically that's made a lot of sense for you. I know what your start up costs were down about $17 million this quarter, and it looks like you're
componenttext: I guess second question if I could. Just you talked a lot about investing in the downturn in strategically historically that's made a lot of sense for you. I know what your start up costs were down about $17 million this quarter, and it looks like you're probably getting pretty close to the end of the portfolio of projects. Should we expect any additional major capital investments going forward?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, the answer to that is yes. Things are winding down with respect to startups, but on with respect to our investments. Jim, you want to add anything?
componenttext: Yes, the answer to that is yes. Things are winding down with respect to startups, but on with respect to our investments. Jim, you want to add anything?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
